Tracking/discussion issue: https://github.com/helium/HIP/issues/338 - HIP https://github.com/helium/HIP/blob/main/0052-iot-dao.md
jamiedubs 01/27/2022 10:54 AM
https://github.com/helium/HIP/issues/338 - Authors: Tushar @tjain-mcc, Shayon - Start Date: 2022-01-04 - Category: Economic / Technical - Status: Draft # Summary This proposal includes a specification of the LoRaWAN Wireless Network Protocol as per the DAO model and L2 implementation outlined in HIP 50. Summary In HIP 50: Helium DAOs, we provide a general structure for onboarding new WNPs to the broader Helium Network, with mechanisms in place to ensure that protocol-specific attributes such as proof-of-coverage rules, data credits pricing, and block validation are within control of the emergent WNT DAO. In this proposal, we specify the implementation of the structure proposed through a detailed onboarding proposal for the LoRaWAN Network. We propose initial configurations of the LoRaWAN economics layer as well as governance mechanisms within the DAO through LoRaWAN (LRW) token voting. # Rendered view https://github.com/helium/HIP/blob/master/0052-lorawan-dao.md

KeithR 01/27/2022 7:39 PM
This is definitely true for one of the stated reasons for the re-denomination; namely unit bias for the earning of rewards. The DAO gets a conversion rate of 1000:1 from the HNT to the HNT.longfi token. Great. However the second primary reason was for the retail purchaser of tokens preferring tokens with low value price point. How does the subDAO solve that issue? It is my understanding that HNT.longfi will not be a tradeable token on the open market. Correct? [mind you, I never really liked the second reason but it was one of the three @JMF used in his argument for the re-denomination.] (edited)

Tushar 01/27/2022 8:25 PM
HNT.longfi (or whatever the ticker this sub DAO token has) would be tradeable on secondary markets because itâ€™s a permissionless token. The bonding curve provides a guaranteed market for the token but itâ€™s not the exclusive market
Tushar
HNT.longfi (or whatever the ticker this sub DAO token has) would be tradeable on secondary markets because itâ€™s a permissionless token. The bonding curve provides a guaranteed market for the token but itâ€™s not the exclusive market
KeithR 01/27/2022 8:26 PM
That's a bummer. Now I really have to worry about picking winners and losers among the subDAOs.
20:33
Won't that create arbitrage scenarios where the price of HNT.subdao drops faster than the bonding curve can adjust the trading ratio of the subDAO token back into HNT? Just to double check, because I am really surprised by your answer. If I start the day with $1000 worth of HNT.longfi tokens, $1000 worth of HNT.5G tokens, and $1000 of HNT tokens, by the end of the day I could have different amounts of value in the three tokens because the market moved in different directions for each of the subtokens? That is, I could now have $500 of HNT.longfi, $2000 of HNT.5G, and $1002 of HNT. (edited)

Since the DAO structure would appear to have been in development without public review since before the vote on HIP-39 (which in itself was perfectly reasonable under the circumstances), I think itâ€™s important to vote again so everybody can make a fully informed decision. Tushar 01/30/2022 11:46 AM
IMO the intention of the redom was never to entice investors with â€œgoing to the moonâ€ or other short term price movements. The intention was to overcome the unit bias for miners. People like mining integer amounts of tokens rather than fractions of tokens, we have heard that many times from many people. IMO the L2 token is a more elegant way to solve this problem. If the community gets new information about something, I think it is reasonable to reconsider a past decision. (edited)

AndrewsMD 01/30/2022 11:55 AM
Small $ Token Investment Bias: Tokens that are priced at a low $ amount are typically seen by the market as â€˜inexpensiveâ€™ regardless of the size of the project's market cap. In general high issuance tokens have benefited from this investment bias because the tokens are perceived to have more upside than higher dollar tokens. Typically, this equates to a higher overall market cap for projects and, in the case of Helium, could help increase the incentive rewards, not only in terms of HNT but also $s per gateway.
AndrewsMD
Small $ Token Investment Bias: Tokens that are priced at a low $ amount are typically seen by the market as â€˜inexpensiveâ€™ regardless of the size of the project's market cap. In general high issuance tokens have benefited from this investment bias because the tokens are perceived to have more upside than higher dollar tokens. Typically, this equates to a higher overall market cap for projects and, in the case of Helium, could help increase the incentive rewards, not only in terms of HNT but also $s per gateway.

AndrewsMD 01/30/2022 1:17 PM

Outside of discord, I have heard words like â€œCluster $&%@â€œ, â€œS-Stormâ€, and â€œWhat the [. . . ]?â€ And we are told that â€œthe communityâ€ wants a revote, because they want to support a new direction for Helium when the â€œcommunityâ€ is still trying to wrap their head around what the true impact of this new direction will be??? There is a risk that such moves could incite fears of mistrust and founder abuse, whether they be warranted or not. We are already seeing evidence of this. In all fairness, you could indeed honor the communityâ€™s wishes who voted to implement HIP39 and subsequently alter HIP52 such that the ratio of HNT to LRW is 1:1. HIP39 was won by 2/3 majority vote of the community. So if you now say that 2/3 of the majority of HNT voting power wants a revote, then that is indeed what will happen. If the 1/3 voting block finds it unpalatable, they can either just suck it up and drink the cool-aid, or move on. One can say it isnâ€™t so, but actions speak louder than words. (edited)

KeithR 01/30/2022 3:10 PM
Well, I will come in uninvited to this discussion. I wholeheartedly vote for HIP39. However I voted for "unit bias for miners" and accepted "small dollar bias for retail investors" as an additional benefit. The vibe I got was that the community wanted the "unit bias for miners" to be 1000:1 but worried about shitcoin perceptions and would have preferred 100:1 for "small dollar bias". HIP 51/52 offer us the opportunity to accomplish both of those wants, though incompatible with each other as one goal. So I actually wouldn't mind a second "are we sure?" vote. My suggestion is that the vote is; Which of these paths forward do you prefer we follow? a) exactly as we voted for HIP39; 1000:1 now. b) bail on HIP39, leave the 1000:1 fix for the LoRaWAN subDAO token as currently stated in HIP52. c) do HIP39 but at 100:1 (meet the wants of the "small dollar bias" folks) and change HIP52 to 100:1 (thus providing 1000:1 to the "unit bias for miners" folks) Someone will probably note how vehemently I was opposed to ever doing the re-denomination more than once. I still think that. However, I think the HIP52 subDAO creation will not be seen as a re-denomination despite the outcome being exactly that. I think everyone will view the 100:1 bonding curve contract as exactly what is to be expected when a subDAO is created and the resulting bonding curve contract parameters being set. (edited)
1
KeithR
Well, I will come in uninvited to this discussion. I wholeheartedly vote for HIP39. However I voted for "unit bias for miners" and accepted "small dollar bias for retail investors" as an additional benefit. The vibe I got was that the community wanted the "unit bias for miners" to be 1000:1 but worried about shitcoin perceptions and would have preferred 100:1 for "small dollar bias". HIP 51/52 offer us the opportunity to accomplish both of those wants, though incompatible with each other as one goal. So I actually wouldn't mind a second "are we sure?" vote. My suggestion is that the vote is; Which of these paths forward do you prefer we follow? a) exactly as we voted for HIP39; 1000:1 now. b) bail on HIP39, leave the 1000:1 fix for the LoRaWAN subDAO token as currently stated in HIP52. c) do HIP39 but at 100:1 (meet the wants of the "small dollar bias" folks) and change HIP52 to 100:1 (thus providing 1000:1 to the "unit bias for miners" folks) Someone will probably note how vehemently I was opposed to ever doing the re-denomination more than once. I still think that. However, I think the HIP52 subDAO creation will not be seen as a re-denomination despite the outcome being exactly that. I think everyone will view the 100:1 bonding curve contract as exactly what is to be expected when a subDAO is created and the resulting bonding curve contract parameters being set. (edited)

KeithR 01/30/2022 9:36 PM
Actually I think I can answer already but it is going to sound flippant but truthfully it is kind of the answer. The reason why HIP39 should wait until after HIP52 is implemented is because the goals of HIP39 will already be embedded in the LoRaWAN subDAO. HIP39 will in fact become redundant at that time. We voted for HIP39 for, because of, and to improve the parameters of the system on behalf of LoRaWAN. The system we are in now will be demoted in a sense to be a child (L2) of the HNT L1 system. We are moving accounts, payment settlement, token minting, and price discovery up a level of abstraction (to the L1). We are keeping LoRaWAN governance, reward calculation, validating, and economic rewards distribution with us and forming the subDAO. The subDAO will have the unit bias solution baked in; that is, the LoRaWAN subtoken will start off as 1/1000 of 1 HNT. The bonding curve contract will provide price determination for all movement of HNT to the LoRaWAN tokens and back; maintaining the coupling of the LoRaWAN token with HNT. "Investors" of LoRaWAN stuff will have the "small dollar bias" baked in as well since the subDAO's token will again start at 1/1000th of 1 HNT. (edited)
21:38
Modifying the HNT token is in a sense unnecessary; which is what we would be doing if implementing HIP39 before HIP52. (edited)
KeithR
Actually I think I can answer already but it is going to sound flippant but truthfully it is kind of the answer. The reason why HIP39 should wait until after HIP52 is implemented is because the goals of HIP39 will already be embedded in the LoRaWAN subDAO. HIP39 will in fact become redundant at that time. We voted for HIP39 for, because of, and to improve the parameters of the system on behalf of LoRaWAN. The system we are in now will be demoted in a sense to be a child (L2) of the HNT L1 system. We are moving accounts, payment settlement, token minting, and price discovery up a level of abstraction (to the L1). We are keeping LoRaWAN governance, reward calculation, validating, and economic rewards distribution with us and forming the subDAO. The subDAO will have the unit bias solution baked in; that is, the LoRaWAN subtoken will start off as 1/1000 of 1 HNT. The bonding curve contract will provide price determination for all movement of HNT to the LoRaWAN tokens and back; maintaining the coupling of the LoRaWAN token with HNT. "Investors" of LoRaWAN stuff will have the "small dollar bias" baked in as well since the subDAO's token will again start at 1/1000th of 1 HNT. (edited)

21:43

Reelen 01/30/2022 9:43 PM

KeithR 01/30/2022 9:46 PM
We could do this another way. We could simply duplicate the entire Helium project for 5G, use the exact incentive model, change the parameters, and create another token; in a sense start another decentralized project. Or... we could take out the parts that apply to any kind of "thing" that we are interested and move them to the L1 and just duplicate and configure the unique parts for each "thing" (L2). In this case, "thing" means "wireless protocol"; but it doesn't have to be wireless protocols only, it could be any kind of service that can benefit from being decentralized. (edited)
21:47
That is the reason for L1 DAO and L2 subDAOs.
21:51
Now why use a bonding curve contract? Utilize price determination rather than price discovery. Have limitless tokens. Have said limitless tokens coupled with your L1 token that is on the open market searching for price discovery. Force the reward structure you desire for rewarding early and late adopters; and all the ones in between. Have unique relative value for each of your subDAOs between each other. Have the same determinate value within all of your subDAOS; HNT in our case.
Reelen 01/30/2022 9:56 PM
Bonding curve concept is going to get complicated for users initially
KeithR 01/30/2022 10:00 PM
It is definitely weird trying to understand how every subToken purchased is more expensive than the next. You can't wait to buy for a better "price". The next one is more expensive by definition. But the inverse is true as well. Every subToken sold is less expensive than the last one sold. You can't wait to sell for a better "price". The next one is less expensive by definition. What you can do though is "wait" for a different location in the queue. You can wait for other people to sell to move the location on the bonding curve to the left (less supply out there) which brings the "price" down (incrementally). If you want to sell, you can wait for other people to buy to move the location on the bonding curve towards the right (more supply out there) which brings the "price" up (incrementally). Now add a level of complexity to this waiting... while you are waiting for a "better" place in the queue, the actual price of HNT could be changing on the open market. If the price of HNT has gone up while you waited for people to sell and move the location on the bonding curve down, you could actually pay more for the subToken than if you hadn't waited. Yes you bought the subTokens for fewer HNT tokens, but the price of the HNT tokens went up more during that time. Weird. (edited)
1
Reelen 01/30/2022 10:01 PM
That brings it together for me better thank you
22:01

KeithR 01/30/2022 10:01 PM
Off to pack for Cancun.

HG 01/31/2022 3:54 AM
Iâ€™m saying it is trivial to adjust the bonding curve to to account for 39, therefore 52 is not materially dependent on the bones/HNT ratio. If the prior implementation of 39 resulted in a need to change 51 (which is the HIP that specifies the subDAO framework) then there would a material impact. But this is not the case. (edited)
04:01
The Bonding curve by definition is a parameter for any subDAO HIP and shouldnâ€™t be used to establish dependencies. Especially since in this case the change would simply be adjusting a multiplicative constant. (edited)

1
HG
39 is not imbedded in 52 because the bonding curve is a variable that can be selected freely as per 51
KeithR 01/31/2022 6:43 AM
The bonding curve is not a variable. It is a strict curve form with specific points on the curve representing each subDAO token. Each token purchase moves the location on the curve to the right and each sale moves the position to the left (current supply of tokens increasing or decreasing). Once that curve is specified at the start of the DAO it is not to be changed. The price of the subtoken denominated in HNT will go up or down depending on where you are on the curve. (edited)
KeithR
The bonding curve is not a variable. It is a strict curve form with specific points on the curve representing each subDAO token. Each token purchase moves the location on the curve to the right and each sale moves the position to the left (current supply of tokens increasing or decreasing). Once that curve is specified at the start of the DAO it is not to be changed. The price of the subtoken denominated in HNT will go up or down depending on where you are on the curve. (edited)
HG 01/31/2022 6:57 AM
It is a variable as it can be different for each subDAO. It doesnâ€™t change once itâ€™s been selected, but it can be selected to account for any bones/HNT ratio that currently exists. As a result, whether 39 is implemented first is immaterial. (edited)
KeithR 01/31/2022 7:07 AM
I get your point but I think using 'variable' in this sense carries too much semantic baggage as it tends to imply well variability. The bonding curve is all about price determination, so there is no variability whatsoever once the form of the curve is selected for the DAO. But yes, as you intended it is true the shape can be any damn shape you want (even stupid shapes). (edited)
07:10
I offer this reason as to why there is a material impact of implementing HIP39 before HIP52; the intentions of HIP39, if done first and thus at the L1 level, will be forced upon every subsequent subDAO that is to be created. (edited)
07:11
This was definitely not considered when we voted on HIP39.
KeithR 01/31/2022 7:19 AM
I can see a scenario (it is probably stupid but I think it makes the point) where a subDAO would actually exhibit large dollar bias. Let's say the subDAO rents time on a yacht. Owners buy yachts, hosts run the boats, rev share. The cost to use will be billions of DCs, and in the desire to payout the least subTokens they will want a larger dollar value of the HNT. I know its kind of lame, but I think it is plausible enough to give an instance where HIP39's intentions could be detrimental to a subsequent subDAO's needs. [by the way, I won't be dying on this hill! I am just trying to offer up an idea of how to think about the issue.] (edited)

AndrewsMD 01/31/2022 1:16 PM
I have concerns with this vote by token lock. I always have been uncertain about this especially when seeing the motivations behind it described in HIP41.
2
13:18
I still donâ€™t see how voting by token lock benefits the small community member. A stronger voting power? More vested? Not really. Consider the following paper napkin example. Lil Jim has 1,000 HNT tokens, while Big John has 10,000. Lil Jim is emotional and feels so strongly about a particular HIP that he blindly lockâ€™s up ALL his HNT for the max time to get max vote power. Big John, says, â€œBased on historical voting patterns on contentious HIPs, my analyst support team projects with 95% confidence that I can lock up 20% of my HNT for the max time to achieve my desired outcome.â€ Are the two equally vested? No. Lil Jim is all in, and Big John is in for 20%. Iâ€™m not saying that Big John is wrong, or that voting power should be wrested from his hands. Quite the contrary. In truth, Helium wouldnâ€™t exist in its current form without the backing of the Big Johnâ€™s of the world. What I am saying is the disparity of voting power has not been changed and it wonâ€™t be changed with this. Is it not better to just say that subDAO LoRaWANs governance is voted on with LWR token votes and subDAO 5G is governed with â€œ5G tokenâ€ votes? What am I missing?
2
AndrewsMD
I have concerns with this vote by token lock. I always have been uncertain about this especially when seeing the motivations behind it described in HIP41.

AndrewsMD 01/31/2022 2:44 PM
It has everything to do with the way it was handled. The community voted. Some feel some kinda way.
1
14:49
But lets get back on task with respect to HIP 52. Allow me to highlight the motivation behind governance by token lock. HIP 41 says, (edited)
14:49
"Most protocol governance in practice today relies on a one-token, one-vote system. This mechanism is vulnerable to adversarial parties borrowing tokens for the solely for the duration of a given vote, and steering the network in a potentially harmful direction. With historical precedent of low voter turnout and low interest rates for short-term loans, this is an easily feasible attack vector. One-token, one vote also concentrates voting power in the hands of large market makers and traders who hold tokens for trading purposes but do not have long term commitment to the network. This can lead to smaller holders becoming disenfranchised and disengaged from governance." Hmmm. (edited)
pirate_rollinson
A question for the authors. How much autonomy do the subDAOs have to create their own governance mechanisms? It is proposed that token holders can 'power up' their vote by token lock, are rules around rough consensus inherited from the HeliumDAO and unchangeable? Can the subDAOs create their own governance models?
Tushar 01/31/2022 6:01 PM
subDAOs control their own governance mechanism. they can do whatever they want (edited)
Steve (dewigo.com)
Its funny because the most simple hip ever, regarding the placement of a decimal, both has the most engagement of all time and to this day spills over into all kinds of places
Tushar 01/31/2022 6:03 PM
I think it's a form of bikeshedding https://thedecisionlab.com/biases/bikeshedding/#:~:text=What%20is%20Bikeshedding%3F,while%20leaving%20important%20matters%20unattended.
edmond@thedecisionlab.com
Bikeshedding - The Decision Lab
Bikeshedding, also known as Parkinsonâ€™s law of triviality, describes our tendency to devote a disproportionate amount of our time to menial and trivial matters while leaving important matters unattended.
2
2
Tushar
I think it's a form of bikeshedding https://thedecisionlab.com/biases/bikeshedding/#:~:text=What%20is%20Bikeshedding%3F,while%20leaving%20important%20matters%20unattended.

KeithR
We could do this another way. We could simply duplicate the entire Helium project for 5G, use the exact incentive model, change the parameters, and create another token; in a sense start another decentralized project. Or... we could take out the parts that apply to any kind of "thing" that we are interested and move them to the L1 and just duplicate and configure the unique parts for each "thing" (L2). In this case, "thing" means "wireless protocol"; but it doesn't have to be wireless protocols only, it could be any kind of service that can benefit from being decentralized. (edited)

Tushar 02/01/2022 11:45 AM
this is a new idea we put in the proposal
11:45
rationale: Note that all manufacturers within the network must stake a minimum of 1,000,000 LRW tokens in order to be whitelisted to receive rewards. If at any point, a manufacturer gives ownership of maintenance and firmware upgrades to a third party, all future manufacturer rewards flow to this new entity.
colton138 02/01/2022 11:48 AM

AndrewsMD 02/02/2022 10:01 AM
@Tushar, I have question regarding voting at L1 vs L2 level. Assume a possible scenario that a change at the L1 level governance level could ultimately impact each subDAO. Thus, if voting were to take place at the L1 level, how would vote power of the subDAO token holder be calculated? Should this be spelled out in HIP51/52? (edited)
Tushar 02/02/2022 11:38 AM
that is an interesting question. i will think about it some more
shayon 02/02/2022 2:16 PM
I am inclined to propose that any governance at the L1 should remain entirely HNT denominated, and there should be no special weighting for subDAOs. In theory, the subDAO can take some portion of the HNT within its bonding curve to participate in the vote (while assessing liquidity risk as per HNT in curve from emissions + network participants). Alternately, subDAO token holders can redeem for HNT or use native HNT to participate in the vote.
14:16
I believe subDAO tokens should only be used for subDAO governance, HNT should only be used for L1 governance.
shayon
I believe subDAO tokens should only be used for subDAO governance, HNT should only be used for L1 governance.
AndrewsMD 02/03/2022 5:08 AM
Hmmmm. Suppose their were changes to the distribution of HNT at the L1 level. Maybe someone doesnâ€™t like the distribution formula. Wouldnâ€™t this give incentive for large and small investors to reduce their supply of subDAO tokens in their bond curve in order to vote? This solution would cause a reflexive reduction in subDAO value for voting purposes. I favor a voting solution that has no direct or indirect reduction in value. (edited)
AndrewsMD
Hmmmm. Suppose their were changes to the distribution of HNT at the L1 level. Maybe someone doesnâ€™t like the distribution formula. Wouldnâ€™t this give incentive for large and small investors to reduce their supply of subDAO tokens in their bond curve in order to vote? This solution would cause a reflexive reduction in subDAO value for voting purposes. I favor a voting solution that has no direct or indirect reduction in value. (edited)
AndrewsMD 02/03/2022 7:20 AM
The simplest answer is to calculate vote power at the conversion rate that the subDAO selected. For example, if the global conversion rate of LRW:HNT is 1,000:1 , then for L1 voting only, 1000 LRW tokens would equal a vote power of 1.
AndrewsMD
The simplest answer is to calculate vote power at the conversion rate that the subDAO selected. For example, if the global conversion rate of LRW:HNT is 1,000:1 , then for L1 voting only, 1000 LRW tokens would equal a vote power of 1.
Anthonyra 02/03/2022 7:35 AM
Or you just have the people in the subDAO vote and then the result of that vote is bubbled up and weighted to the amount of HNT bonded to the subDAO. The only issue here is voting on L1 will become kinda tedious for people in multiple subDAO's. But I guess, it's part of the hassle with working with multiple subDAO's. Essentially each subDAO votes as a whole for L1. (edited)

KeithR 02/14/2022 8:02 PM
You are sort of correct. The cool thing about the 5G usage is that the actual customers do not have to do anything (cell phone users who walk into the bar or restaurant where my 5g hotspot is being utilized). They just use their phone as they normally do. Since my hotspot will be the "best" service available in the bar, the phone will choose to use it. Nothing else needed. The phone user's provider (Tmobile or Verizon in this example) will pay for their usage with DCs to Helium. The Helium network then pays me the hNT equivalent.

AndrewsMD 02/19/2022 9:53 AM
Iâ€™m posting this in this channel as well. Given the loud objections to a 0.9% reduction in HNT earnings so that we can have a better functioning network and blockchain, I wonder what kind of outcry will be seen when mainstream learns about the earnings reductions associated with HIPs 51&52. LoRaWAN token holders will feel the bite from the following: -) 10% cold bucket funding; -) 2% incentive to manufactures; -) 0.6% in fees (to & fro the bond curve); -) 0.9% reduction from HIP55; -) Two layers of validation work (L1 & L2); -) Prorata share of HNT emissions to the LoRaWAN subDAO; -) Reduced value of LRW token:HNT per the bond curve. At least in the short term. For example, assuming everyone who earns LRW tokens HODLs their LRW tokens for 4 years (i.e., no one converts LRW back to HNT for 4 years), how many months will it take for the supply of HNT in the LoRaWAN subDAO bond curve to build before 1,000 LRW tokens will approximately = 1 HNT? Furthermore, if HIPS51,52,53 donâ€™t get implemented until 6 months from now, the 8/2023 emissions halving will have to be factored into the equation to answer that question. Itâ€™s best to be transparent.
2

Iâ€™m posting this in this channel as well. Given the loud objections to a 0.9% reduction in HNT earnings so that we can have a better functioning network and blockchain, I wonder what kind of outcry will be seen when mainstream learns about the earnings reductions associated with HIPs 51&52. LoRaWAN token holders will feel the bite from the following: -) 10% cold bucket funding; -) 2% incentive to manufactures; -) 0.6% in fees (to & fro the bond curve); -) 0.9% reduction from HIP55; -) Two layers of validation work (L1 & L2); -) Prorata share of HNT emissions to the LoRaWAN subDAO; -) Reduced value of LRW token:HNT per the bond curve. At least in the short term. For example, assuming everyone who earns LRW tokens HODLs their LRW tokens for 4 years (i.e., no one converts LRW back to HNT for 4 years), how many months will it take for the supply of HNT in the LoRaWAN subDAO bond curve to build before 1,000 LRW tokens will approximately = 1 HNT? Furthermore, if HIPS51,52,53 donâ€™t get implemented until 6 months from now, the 8/2023 emissions halving will have to be factored into the equation to answer that question. Itâ€™s best to be transparent.

Matthew SoCal 02/20/2022 7:29 PM

Don't make the mistake I did of saying there's 500k end users at the table. That was brutal. To make it worse, I switch to saying there's dog and cattle trackers. Had my ass handed to me.

lysanderG 02/21/2022 11:36 AM
Terminology is very confusing in the LoRa/Helium space. Primarily due to the fact that networking sensors/endpoints wirelessly is newish. "Sensors" are the true "end user" as you call it on LoRaWANs. "Trackers" like the dog collar you mention are really "sensors" in that they sense the GPS location of the tracker. Most any endpoint on Helium is really a combination of a LoRa radio with a sensor buit into a single device. Does "CBA" stand for "cost benefit analysis?" (edited)
lysanderG
Terminology is very confusing in the LoRa/Helium space. Primarily due to the fact that networking sensors/endpoints wirelessly is newish. "Sensors" are the true "end user" as you call it on LoRaWANs. "Trackers" like the dog collar you mention are really "sensors" in that they sense the GPS location of the tracker. Most any endpoint on Helium is really a combination of a LoRa radio with a sensor buit into a single device. Does "CBA" stand for "cost benefit analysis?" (edited)
Matthew SoCal 02/21/2022 12:05 PM
Yes, cost benefit analysis. As "sensors" go, they'll only fit into a CBA for an "As-Built" type project where the engineering and construction is being done congruently. Maybe in the "private sector" these kinds of speculations can be reasoned, but when the contracts are based on bonds....it won't fly. Otherwise, there needs to be end user products that can have forecasting for x number of years depending on funding source and regulatory requirements. (edited)

Why not let the formula for the LoRaWAN Programmatic Treasury be P = S^1.1 x 10^-3 ??? In this way, it would correlate to the planned LoRaWAN emissions rate.

@Tushar Thanks for attempting to answer my question during the DeWi Monthly call, but the motive behind the question had less to do with HIP39, and more to do with value of the LoRaWAN subDAO token. I didn't want to take up too much time on the community call with my question and opted to ask a follow up here. If the proposed LoRaWAN emissions rate is planned to be 1 HNT : 1 LRW x 10^3, and the LoRaWAN Programmatic Treasury formula is â€œroughlyâ€ equivalent to 1HNT: 1 LRW x 10^ -8, would that not decrease the innate value of each LRW subDAO token by approximately 10^-5? Why not let the formula for the LoRaWAN Programmatic Treasury be P = S^1.1 x 10^-3 ??? In this way, it would correlate to the planned LoRaWAN emissions rate.
Tushar 02/23/2022 10:05 AM
we needed to make 10^-8 because that is what allowed the math to work out to make sure hotspots are mining full integer numbers of tokens into the future as the supply of LRW increases which also increases the price of LRW according to that formula
10:06
we have been more focused on the structural ideas in the proposal first and plan to go through a process to tweak all the variables once the structure is more set

KeithR 02/28/2022 2:12 PM
It seems to me that validators should not be subDAO-specific from an "ownership" perspective. Stay separate from everything. Yes, the subDAO might have specific software and rules, policies, payment schemes, etc; they just don't get staked with subDAO tokens. Stake with HNT but payout in subDAO-specific tokens (since the payout comes from the epochal minting).
14:19
I have become a lot more fond of the programmatic treasury/bonding curve concept knowing that the subDAO token minting is one-way only. Every host/owner of a hotspot now gets the chance to have one of the first 812,500 tokens. Does anyone know the average hold time of an earned HNT token? If we did, we can model out a potential growth curve of the programmatic treasury. It will be very very interesting to see people's sell behavior given the enormous increase in HNT-value for a subDAO token at the mind-boggling pace that it increases.

KeithR 03/15/2022 10:20 AM
I have to disagree. The math behind the programmatic treasuries really really rewards the early tokens that are mined. If folks HODL their subDAO tokens, they will be very very happy.
samlew 03/15/2022 11:15 AM
@KeithR im not as techincal in this area as you. Do you mind explaining programmatic treasuries? So let's say as a hypothetical example someone had 20,000 HNT. What happens when this change goes into effect?
11:15
Are they retroactively given subdao tokens? explain why you think its beneficial. Maybe I misudnerstand
KeithR 03/15/2022 11:44 AM
You can only get the subDAO tokens via earning them as rewards (for mining and maybe for validators). Technically you could buy them off someone else too; peer-to-peer or maybe even through some exchange. But as every single token is minted, the cost (in HNT) of the next token goes up. price = supply^1.1 * 10^-3 [the equation in the docs says 10^-8; @AndrewsMD & I think it is wrong, Tushar is looking into it] The "supply to the power of 1.1" means the price curve is rather nicely steep. If you hold your earned subToken for even a reasonable amount of time, the price you get for selling it back (which really means converting it back to HNT) is pretty sweet. We are really going to want to encourage each other to hold hold hold. The sell pressure is going to be huge; and don't forget, since it is a programmatic treasury, the price comes down at the exact same steep-ness of the price curve. Each subToken sold is less than the last one sold. The brilliance of this is that the price curve (expressed via the equation and priced in HNT) is that it represents price determination not price discovery like a regular market-based trade scenario. (edited)
samlew 03/15/2022 11:45 AM
lol that is all still above my head
11:45

11:46

KeithR 03/15/2022 11:51 AM
While I am not a financial advisor, I think the enticement will be to hold the tokens you earn in the form you earn them. If you earn LoRa subTokens, hold them for as long as you can and encourage everyone else to hold too. If you have a 5G set up or many, you will be enticed to hold the 5G subTokens. Your Helium app will assuredly show how many of each kind of token you have and the value in HNT that those various tokens currently represent. So it will be easy enough to know how well you are doing.

samlew

KeithR 03/15/2022 5:59 PM
Disagree. From the perspective you wrote, your only choice is to invest in HNT; you can't buy into any of the subDAO tokens per se. Technically you could buy them off of someone else peer-to-peer and if that happens a lot I suppose an exchange could elect to offer the service. If you earn the subTokens via your hotspot or your validator stake, then yes you have to make a decision of sorts whether to hold that subToken or convert it back to HNT via the programmatic treasury (by the way, this would be the only way to get HNT from the subToken). The programmatic treasury price curve has a significant enticement to hold your subTokens built into it (the supply to the power of 1.1 part).
AndrewsMD
Itâ€™s currently a work in process. We would have to have a vote first. Hopefully by Q4?
samlew 03/15/2022 6:02 PM

samlew

AndrewsMD 03/15/2022 6:30 PM
We are in staunch agreement. Some finer critical details to work out, but flying at 30,000 feet, itâ€™s phenomenal. I call it Helium 2.0
KeithR 03/25/2022 3:03 AM
Sorry for the very long post but I need some help big time! I have been trying to truly grok the programmatic treasury curve and its effect on the cost, in HNT, of each subtoken. Well, here I am weeks in and I am worried about my understanding. Can someone that understands math please check my work? fact 1: the programmatic treasury mints subtokens at price = (supply ^ 1.1 ) * (10 ^ -8) [this is the equation in the docs. Seems to imply that 100,000,000 subtokens per 1 HNT. this is why some of us think it should be (10 ^ -3 ); 1,000 subtokens to 1 HNT - to reflect the intention of the re-denomination goal, HIP39, of 1000:1 but let's stick with 10^-8 for this conversation ] fact 2: 10^5 = 100,000. on your calculator, pressing 10 [x^y button] 5 = 100,000 fact 3: 10^-8 = 1/100,000,000 = 0.00000001 = 10 [x^y] -8 = 0.00000001 (so I can substitute this in the equation if I want) . (edited)
03:03
Q1: what is the cost, in HNT, of the very first subtoken? That is, current supply is zero and we want to mint the first one. gut feeling 1: seems like it should be 1/100,000,000 of 1 HNT Answer 1: ( 0 [x^y] 1.1 )* 0.00000001 = 0 that's funny, the very first one is free Q2: what is the cost, in HNT, of the second subtoken? That is, current supply is one and we want to mint the second one. gut feeling 1: seems like it should be 1/100,000,000 of 1 HNT plus a smidgeon more Answer 1: ( 1 [x^y] 1.1 ) * 0.00000001 = 0.00000001 not a problem. since the first one was actually free, the second one I guess should be the gut feeling from Q1. It is. 1/100,000,000 of 1 HNT. Q3: what is the cost, in HNT, of the third subtoken? That is, current supply is two and we want to mint the third one. gut feeling 1: really seems like it should be 1/100,000,000 of 1 HNT plus a smidgeon more Answer 1: ( 2 [x^y] 1.1 ) * 0.00000001 = 0.000000021435469 of 1 HNT Well that seems crazy! 2.14 times as much? . (edited)
03:03
Q4: Second to last one. what is the cost, in HNT, of the fourth subtoken? That is, supply is 3 and we are minting the 4th one. Answer 4: ( 4 [x^y] 1.1 ) * 0.00000001 = 0.000000045947934 of 1 HNT. Yikes! That is 2.14 times as much again. Q5. Last one, I promise. what is the cost, in HNT, of the 5,001st subtoken? That is, supply is 5000 and we are minting one more. Answer 5. ( 5000 [x^y] 1.1 ) * 0.00000001 = 0.00011718364558 of 1 HNT. That is 11,718 times the cost of the second subtoken. Someone please tell me what I am doing wrong. Please. My answers match the table in the documents, but I am off by one in "supply". It seems the equation is using "supply" to mean "the resulting number of tokens after this next single subtoken minting". Ok fine, but that doesn't change the insane increase in price, in HNT, of the very next subtoken. This seems to be a criminal amount of profit being built in. By the way, if I am doing this correctly (and I don't think I am despite getting the same exact numbers as the document) the 18,738,175th subToken will cost an entire HNT token. (edited)

That is, current supply is two and we want to mint the third one. gut feeling 1: really seems like it should be 1/100,000,000 of 1 HNT plus a smidgeon more Answer 1: ( 2 [x^y] 1.1 ) * 0.00000001 = 0.000000021435469 of 1 HNT Well that seems crazy! 2.14 times as much? . shayon 03/26/2022 1:14 AM
The programmatic treasury formula defines price as a function of supply, P = (S^(1.1))*(10^-8). For each of the questions, you can arrive at the price by plugging in S=nth token
01:14
Note that this price is in HNT
01:17
If at any point given the supply of LRW you wish to find how much HNT is in the treasury (H), you can take the integral of the original term i.e. H = (S^2.1)/(2.1*10^8).
01:19
Then you can also work backwards and find the total supply given HNT in the curve i.e. S = (H * 2.1 * 10^8)/(1/2.1)
01:23
So for example, letâ€™s say there is 1000 HNT in the treasury at epoch 1, and 200 HNT are about to flow in during epoch 2. At epoch 1, the supply for LRW is given by (1000* 2.1 * 10^8)^(1/2.1) = 246,339. The price of LRW per the treasury is (1000^1.1)*(10^-8) = 0.00852 (edited)
01:24
Once the emission hits in epoch 2, there is now 1200 HNT in the curve. At epoch 2, the supply for LRW is given by (1200* 2.1* 10^8)^(1/2.1) = 268,682. The price of LRW per the treasury is (1000^1.1)*(10^-8) = 0.00938 (edited)
01:25
The new LRW tokens minted is 268,682 - 246,339 = 22,343
shayon
So for example, letâ€™s say there is 1000 HNT in the treasury at epoch 1, and 200 HNT are about to flow in during epoch 2. At epoch 1, the supply for LRW is given by (1000* 2.1 * 10^8)^(1/2.1) = 246,339. The price of LRW per the treasury is (1000^1.1)*(10^-8) = 0.00852 (edited)
AndrewsMD 03/26/2022 9:59 AM
Can we run this math one more time? You said â€œThe price of LRW per the treasury is (1000^1.1)*(10^-8) = 0.00852â€. Is 0.00852 correct?
10:01
(1,000 ^1.1) = 1,195.26 Then simply move the decimal over to the left by 8 places. Am I missing something?
KeithR 03/26/2022 9:03 PM
So I am going to take a more extreme position now. I was hanging out with my friend's college-aged kid (Isaac) today and he is closer in time to integrals than me (25 years since college which means 26 years since integrals for me when I finished my mathematics minor). Isaac concluded that the equation is simply wrong; to which I agreed. That is, unless the intention is really to give 11,718x profit to the 5,001st token and damn near infinite profit to the 18 millionth token. Which I really hope it is not, as that is basically a criminal amount of built-in profit. So, what to do next? I assume I need to defend this position against the group for a bit to get a few others to agree. Once I get others to see the error of the equation, then what? Or do I need to bring forth a better equation now too? Isaac and I started to develop a new equation to provide the price determination we are looking for from a programmatic treasury. I have the beginnings of said equation but it requires some discussion around weighting. But I am going to hold off on that until we get past this first part. That is, getting you'all to agree with my position that the equation, as clarified in the documentation, does not work as intended. (edited)

shayon 03/27/2022 7:55 AM
I donâ€™t understand what you mean here â€” how do you define in-built profit and where does it come from for any given holder? the holder of the 18 millionth token is not in any privileged position over any other token holder, they can all redeem against the treasury at any time

AndrewsMD 03/27/2022 9:11 AM
Thanks for that. Shayon, is there anywhere in the edited HIP52 that proposes what the LRW emissions are proposed to be? For example and excluding the 0.3% transaction fee, if in epoch 1, the L1 allocated 100 HNT to the LRW subDAO (L2), how many LRW tokens will be minted? If the answer is 100 HNT = 100 x 10^8 LRW, then all makes sense. But if it is less than 100 x 10^8, there is a crazy and significant HNT devaluation built into LoRaWAN hotspot network participation. We canâ€™t afford a typo in the emissions formula or the programmatic treasury formula. I remember Capcom and Tushar saying that they would look into this, but I havenâ€™t seen an edited version yet that addresses this. Am I looking in the wrong place?
09:12
Correction. Capcom noted the probability of an unintended error, and Tushar said he would look into it.
shayon
I donâ€™t understand what you mean here â€” how do you define in-built profit and where does it come from for any given holder? the holder of the 18 millionth token is not in any privileged position over any other token holder, they can all redeem against the treasury at any time
KeithR 03/27/2022 9:48 AM
The privileged position is the person that earned the first subToken at 0.00000001 HNT. Since the price of each subToken is based on the supply before to the power of 1.1, the price steps up each and every single token. Every next earned subToken is more expensive than the last. The 18,738,175th subToken will cost basically an entire HNT token. That is 100,000,000x profit between the first and the last in this example. p = ( 18,738,174 ^ 1.1 ) * 0.00000001 = 0.99999998658011 HNT
AndrewsMD
Thanks for that. Shayon, is there anywhere in the edited HIP52 that proposes what the LRW emissions are proposed to be? For example and excluding the 0.3% transaction fee, if in epoch 1, the L1 allocated 100 HNT to the LRW subDAO (L2), how many LRW tokens will be minted? If the answer is 100 HNT = 100 x 10^8 LRW, then all makes sense. But if it is less than 100 x 10^8, there is a crazy and significant HNT devaluation built into LoRaWAN hotspot network participation. We canâ€™t afford a typo in the emissions formula or the programmatic treasury formula. I remember Capcom and Tushar saying that they would look into this, but I havenâ€™t seen an edited version yet that addresses this. Am I looking in the wrong place?
KeithR 03/27/2022 10:44 PM
The LRW emissions from any given epoch is determined by how many can be "paid for" by however much HNT was minted into the LoRaWAN's programmatic treasury which is turn based on how many Data Credits the wireless protocol burned in relation to the other wireless protocols. Current HNT mint is 2,500,000 HNT per month; 64.1% goes to PoC and traffic (DC burn). So 1,602,500. Let's say in the beginning that the amount of PoC and DC burn is even between LoRa and 5G. So then LoRa DAO gets 801,250 HNT that month. To make the math easier, let's make this the very first month. So subToken supply is at zero at the start of the month. Miracles happen and no one converts any of their subTokens back into HNT during the month. What is supply at the end of the month? I get 5,946,750 subTokens (plus some change as a fraction of one HNT). Anyone think I have the wrong answer? If not, do you see why there is a criminal amount of profit built in? If my numbers are correct, 5.9 million subTokens where the profit margin between 1 and 5,001 subTokens is 11,718x. So HODLing your subTokens for just one month will net you an unbelievable amount of profit if most people don't immediately convert back into HNT. (edited)
KeithR
The LRW emissions from any given epoch is determined by how many can be "paid for" by however much HNT was minted into the LoRaWAN's programmatic treasury which is turn based on how many Data Credits the wireless protocol burned in relation to the other wireless protocols. Current HNT mint is 2,500,000 HNT per month; 64.1% goes to PoC and traffic (DC burn). So 1,602,500. Let's say in the beginning that the amount of PoC and DC burn is even between LoRa and 5G. So then LoRa DAO gets 801,250 HNT that month. To make the math easier, let's make this the very first month. So subToken supply is at zero at the start of the month. Miracles happen and no one converts any of their subTokens back into HNT during the month. What is supply at the end of the month? I get 5,946,750 subTokens (plus some change as a fraction of one HNT). Anyone think I have the wrong answer? If not, do you see why there is a criminal amount of profit built in? If my numbers are correct, 5.9 million subTokens where the profit margin between 1 and 5,001 subTokens is 11,718x. So HODLing your subTokens for just one month will net you an unbelievable amount of profit if most people don't immediately convert back into HNT. (edited)
AndrewsMD 03/27/2022 11:42 PM
My calculations are similar with the exception of one part. Please correct me if Iâ€™m wrong. In an effort to simplify this, letâ€™s assume for a moment that existing hotspots that are currently earning 0.10 HNT/day will now receive 100 LRW tokens per day. This is what was previously proposed/intended (ie., 1:1000 - the unit bias thing). To make this easily understandable, if you give me $1 USD, I will give you $1,000 in Monopoly money back to which you can later convert back to USD when you want. Then I tell you that you will get your USD back from the monopoly bank when we go through a programmatic treasury of which P=S^1.1 x 10 ^-8. Since in this scenario supply is $1,000 of Monopoly money, at the time you want your cash in USD back, you will only get back $0.00002 USD. Thatâ€™s a crazy fraction of a penny. But if the supply is $5,000 of Monopoly money, you will get back $0.00011 USD back. Thatâ€™s a 450% improvement in price in comparison, but itâ€™s still just a fraction of a penny. In the end, you are still upset cause you lost your dollar. You would tell me, thatâ€™s not fair. â€Give me back my dollar, or Iâ€™ll slap you like Will Smith. That is criminal!â€ â€”â€” Now, Using your example, and plugging in 5,946,750 into the formula of Price in HNT = supply of LRW tokens^1.1 x 10^-8 => P= (5,946,750^1.1) x (10 ^-8) = 0.28 in HNT. In short, for a total of 5.9 million LRW tokens, you only get back 0.28 HNT. What am I missing?
KeithR 03/27/2022 11:45 PM
Because the programmatic treasury has not been configured to handout 1000:1 subToken-to-token ratio. Which by the way, suggests that the re-denomination will actually happen before HIP52! (edited)
1
23:46
0.28 HNT for a single LRW subToken is an amazing deal if you sell it back using the token you earned at the beginning of the month that cost 0.00000001 HNT.
23:47
That is called a criminal amount of profit.
23:49
[your mistake in the post above is the p value is for a single monopoly bill not the entire amount of monopoly money.] (edited)
KeithR

AndrewsMD 03/27/2022 11:50 PM
Interesting. I need to think about that.
KeithR 03/27/2022 11:52 PM
Which actually brings us to the dark side of a programmatic treasury... If you install a hotspot towards the end of the month and no one has sold yet. You earn your first batch of LRW tokens. Then everyone runs to the door to convert their LRW tokens back into HNT while you were sleeping. Guess what, you just lost a lot of value from those tokens you earned. Now the consolation prize is that the tokens you earn now will cost a lot fewer HNT to convert. So now you can be ready to front run the late suckers the next month.
AndrewsMD 03/27/2022 11:53 PM
Wow.
AndrewsMD
Interesting. I need to think about that.
KeithR 03/27/2022 11:53 PM
You have to do the integral to calculate the area of the curve to find out the total cost of HNT for a batch of subTokens between two supply values.
1
KeithR
You have to do the integral to calculate the area of the curve to find out the total cost of HNT for a batch of subTokens between two supply values.
AndrewsMD 03/27/2022 11:54 PM
That makes sense
KeithR 03/27/2022 11:56 PM
I think this where the mistake happened for why this equation was chosen. I suspect they confirmed that yes they could reliable go both ways between HNT to LRW and back but only went up to 5000 subtokens. The equation works reasonably nicely if the total supply stays under about 20,000 subtokens. Once you get to 100,000 subtokens, the curve goes parabolic towards infinity. By then it is too late; insane profit becomes nonsense and supply means nothing.
KeithR 03/28/2022 12:38 AM
My other hypothesis of the root cause of the error is that someone added up the 10% cold bucket and the 0.3% treasury fee in their head and figured that 'to the power of 1.1' meant a 10% growth over increasing supply to offset the two fees. Well it doesn't; because of exponentiation.
00:41
00:44
I borrowed this from wikipedia. It shows clearly that any exponent above 1 goes parabolic; even 1.1. Therein lies the problem with the equation as is in the documentation. (edited)
KeithR
Because the programmatic treasury has not been configured to handout 1000:1 subToken-to-token ratio. Which by the way, suggests that the re-denomination will actually happen before HIP52! (edited)
KeithR 03/28/2022 1:03 AM
Thinking about the re-denomination in relation to the programmatic treasury concept. It serves only a single purpose to use a programmatic treasury to solve the 1000:1 re-denomination needs. Programmatic treasuries are about price determination, not price discovery. So, yes you could force the emissions rate to generate subtokens 1000 times as many HNT as you put in. OK, fine. But since it is a programmatic treasury, it stays at 1000:1 going in and 1:1000 going out. No benefit other than earning "more" tokens. The benefit of the re-denomination is that price discovery potentially allows the ratio to be 'forgotten' and the value of the tokens to increase more than the re-denomination ratio. Seems kind of silly to just increase the tokens but not allow the value to change; that's just a gimmick. "You don't like one-tenth of a dollar? Is a dime better? No? OK, how about ten pennies? Still not enough? OK, fine, here is 1000 one-hundredth pennies. Now you have a lot!" Not really. So if you want all of the promised benefits of re-denomination from HIP39, you need to ensure that it gets done before HIP52. Multiple claims and promises have been made that this is the case; so let's just be vigilant over our leaders to ensure it does indeed happen. (edited)
1
01:08
. . Had a side conversation with @AndrewsMD and from it, we would like to make the suggestion that the following data requirement be added to the HIP52 documentation (and the other HIPs like it). It is to be required that the current supply of the subDAO tokens be clearly and transparently reported in the Helium app and be available for viewing on the explorer web site. Reporting of the number of tokens in supply, the amount of HNT in the treasury, and the current single subToken price be reported in real-time just like the current number of hotspots, validators, and oracle prices are reported. (edited)
2
KeithR
. . Had a side conversation with @AndrewsMD and from it, we would like to make the suggestion that the following data requirement be added to the HIP52 documentation (and the other HIPs like it). It is to be required that the current supply of the subDAO tokens be clearly and transparently reported in the Helium app and be available for viewing on the explorer web site. Reporting of the number of tokens in supply, the amount of HNT in the treasury, and the current single subToken price be reported in real-time just like the current number of hotspots, validators, and oracle prices are reported. (edited)

And I agree with your point that I too do not think Helium will have any issue adding the requirement to the documentation. They have nothing to hide here. I just want to make sure the feature is added to the Helium app so a person can easily see where on the curve the price point of the treasury is located. (edited)

KeithR 03/29/2022 5:09 PM
I like that approach as it doesn't require the app to be constantly querying for the current stats. A button to query for the price, count, and curve location works; also means you can get more stats at the same time (uptick and downtick rates over a few periods of time (minute. hour, day, maybe week as well) and some sort of graphic representation of the current state of affairs (I am not an artist...a graph? pie charts? I don't know). Thank you.

I don't know). Thank you.

I was more thinking about the rate the DNT supply is increasing or decreasing. 1H: <-- 23,054 --> 34,405 [the treasury is filling up over the hour] 1D: <-- 268,255 --> 134,405 [over the day the treasury has decreased] 1W: blah, bah, blah (edited)

KeithR 04/05/2022 9:49 PM
Idea for an additional feature. Or it could be a refinement of how to display the data above. Have the ability to enter the number of DNT and have the app return the current 'bid price' and the number of HNT to which that number of DNT will be converted. The default value would be 1 so that the user can only press the button to find out the bid price, subDAO token supply, etc.
21:54
If a number of DNT other than 1 was entered, the returned page could facilitate the conversion by providing a subsequent button to initiate the conversion. Would love to see the function of converting HNT to DNT and the other function of DNT to HNT be given two verbs that are similar but different. I don't think HNT to DNT can be called minting; as the HNT was minted and subsequently deposited into the treasury (at which time it becomes DNT). Withdrawing the DNT out to HNT could use the already existing burn metaphor, but given it is a programmatic treasury that seems a weak reuse of the verb.
cinimod 04/06/2022 10:10 AM
Is it possible my mined DNT could be converted into x amount of HNT one day and y amount of HNT the next?
KeithR 04/06/2022 10:32 AM
Absolutely. It would depend on how many tokens had been withdrawn or deposited into the treasury between your two events. If they change the equation (which we just found out they are in the process of revising) to a linear equation with a slope of 0, then "no every DNT would be priced the same". I do not believe we will get a slope of 0; it seems there is every intention to reward early earners by building a price increase for every next token.
cinimod 04/06/2022 11:47 AM
Ok, I'll lurk and wait for future updates on that.
11:50
Is it planned the only way MNT can be created is through the minting contract? Or could i take some of my HNT and turn it into MNT (when these subdao hips get approved and implemented of course) ?
KeithR 04/06/2022 11:51 AM
a spot price equation of p = slope * supply * 10^-n would give you an increasing reward for holders of earlier tokens, a reward for being earlier than someone else, and a mechanism for solving unit bias as well. The value for slope would be decided simply by how much reward you would like to give to early earners. The value for n would be decided by how long you want to avoid people complaining about fewer than whole tokens being earned. (edited)
cinimod
Is it planned the only way MNT can be created is through the minting contract? Or could i take some of my HNT and turn it into MNT (when these subdao hips get approved and implemented of course) ?
KeithR 04/06/2022 11:53 AM
The only way to get the subDAO token (DNT seems to be the shorthand) is for HNT to be deposited into the treasury via minting (this is a requirement that the HIP has imposed; and very much to my liking).
11:55
You can at any time trade DNT with someone else but you would be setting the price between you two; it would not affect the actual spot price though. The only way the spot price is changed is by HNT being deposited into the treasury or DNT being withdrawn (which means it is converted back into HNT) and thus supply being changed. (edited)
cinimod 04/06/2022 11:55 AM
Thanks for clearing that up.
KeithR 04/06/2022 11:56 AM
Of course, they may change all of this in their next revision.
11:56
I think they are very close to a near perfect strategy to accomplish the need for handling any number of wireless protocols (or whatever DAO we might create to utilize the HNT economic incentive model). (edited)
11:58
We need subDAOs for sure; each protocol needs its own governance rules, their own payout schedules, and their own mechanisms for internal funding. (edited)
KeithR
Absolutely. It would depend on how many tokens had been withdrawn or deposited into the treasury between your two events. If they change the equation (which we just found out they are in the process of revising) to a linear equation with a slope of 0, then "no every DNT would be priced the same". I do not believe we will get a slope of 0; it seems there is every intention to reward early earners by building a price increase for every next token.

KeithR 04/07/2022 12:45 PM
I think it is pointless because of the zero slope. There is no need to convert to a subToken if it is simply 1 HNT gets you 1000 DNT (LoRaWAN tokens) and the same in reverse (minus transaction fees). One of the stated goals (I acknowledge that it was mentioned very early in the process) was to reward early earners/adopters in the subDAO. A zero slope does not do this. Unless there is a significant difference in approach, using an integral to compute the "cost" to deposit 5,385 HNT or to convert back out out 13,730 DNT is not any more difficult to a computer than multiplying or dividing by 1000. (edited)
12:50

AndrewsMD 04/07/2022 1:43 PM
There is a connection that you missed, or more likely, I simply failed to explain appropriately. Token rewards at the L1 level will be distributed to the L2 levels in a fashion that incents the growth of Data Credit Usage in the Helium Ecosystem. Full stop. Without Data Credit usage, this token has no real sustainable value aside from hype like Doge and Shiba. So if it is in the community's best interest to shift rewards or value of said rewards to one subDAO vs another, it is of no consequence to the HNT hodler. For the HNT hodler desires growth in the value of the native token. I take a contrarian view on the comment that "the programmatic treasury has no effect on increasing DC spend". Its quite the opposite, . . . just not directly. The correct programmatic treasury formula (if designed right) will yield incentive that spins the flywheel in the areas most needed, which in turn yields (or should yield) increased DC spending. HIPs 51, 52 & 53 are being designed to elevate the entire Helium Ecosystem today, and in the future. I look forward to seeing the revised HIPs. (edited)
KeithR 04/07/2022 3:29 PM

ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 04/08/2022 3:51 PM

KeithR 04/08/2022 3:52 PM
If the DNT is denominated in HNT, then there is no difference between the two unless there is either price discovery or price determination within the DNT economy. If you use price discovery, then arbitrage exists at all times between the secondary market of DNT and the withdrawal of HNT from the treasury via DNT conversion. If there is price determination with a slope of zero, then DNT is moving lock step with the value of the HNT. Just leave it as HNT then.
capcom
DC consumption for example will require DNT burning
KeithR 04/08/2022 3:55 PM
Where is this in the documentation? DCs have always been pegged to the USD and "created" via burning of HNT. But again, if the DNT is denominated in HNT, then just keep it in HNT. Unless you have a treasury with a non-zero slope (probably has to be positive too).
KeithR 04/08/2022 4:03 PM
I currently think the programmatic treasury equation for LoRaWAN should be price (denominated in HNT) = 1.01 * totalsupply * ( 10^-8 ) It generates 12,684,286 subTokens (DNT) for 812,500.048 HNT (the current monthly mint and taking out HST, validators and assuming that 50% of DC burn is done in LoRaWAN for the time being) per month. The 5,001st token is worth 0.0000505 HNT ($0.012 USD) and the last token is worth 0.1281112785 HNT ($3.07 USD) @ HNT price of $24 and assuming no one converts their DNT back into HNT during the month. It pays to invest. It pays to hold. And unit bias is solved for a very long time coming. Throw in a requirement for a few hundred million DNT to be tied up in validators, and you have well rewarded the early earners. If you want to decrease the difference in value between the first and last token, you simply add more zeros between the decimal and the trailing 1 (1.0001 for instance). (edited)
16:08
I chose 10^-8 over 10^-7. While I like there only be 4 million-ish tokens per month (under the assumptions I made) from 10^-7, I prefer the smaller profit difference between the first and last token of 10^-8.
KeithR 04/08/2022 4:16 PM
@AndrewsMD just reminded me that the 0.6% withdrawal fee stays in the totalsupply. I need to think more about the effects of that, but it seems that decreases the effect of a withdrawal in comparison to the effect on supply of a deposit. Does the 0.3% cold start fee only affect the deposits or does that come out of the withdrawals as well? (edited)
KeithR
@AndrewsMD just reminded me that the 0.6% withdrawal fee stays in the totalsupply. I need to think more about the effects of that, but it seems that decreases the effect of a withdrawal in comparison to the effect on supply of a deposit. Does the 0.3% cold start fee only affect the deposits or does that come out of the withdrawals as well? (edited)
AndrewsMD 04/08/2022 4:17 PM
Transaction fees are 0.3% going into the treasury and 0.3% coming out of the treasury.

AndrewsMD 04/08/2022 4:45 PM
I happen to agree with Capcom, at least until I see the revised formula. This is where we differ or I have identified a learning opportunity for me. â€œ1 HNT gets you x DNT (minus fees).â€ Please correct my understanding. Step 1) The L2 gets allocated HNT for rewards/use. Step 2) The L2 then emits subDAO tokens at whatever ratio governance agrees to of HNT: #DNT (minus 0.3%). This could be 1HNT:1,000 DNT or even 1 HNT: DNT x 10^8 Then when the DNT hodler, wants to convert their DNT back into HNT using the programmatic treasury, they do so using a specific formula minus another 0.3% fee. The first proposed formula has a linear slope and the new one coming up has a zero slope. In my opinion, the slope refers to the rate of change in conversion returns. As long as the positive amount of emission is commensurate with the negative conversion rate out of the programmatic treasury, all is well provided that the treasury has the supply of HNT to meet all current and future conversions of DNT back to HNT. I personally need to see the proposed formula with a zero slope before I can render an opinion on its viability. To KiethRâ€™s point however, a zero slope rewards all DNT holders equally regardless of the level of supply. In this scenario, there is no positive or negative incentive to hodl DNT.

Is the value from each dnt having governance by the holders of dnt
AndrewsMD 04/08/2022 4:46 PM

16:48

KeithR

AndrewsMD 04/08/2022 4:53 PM

KeithR 04/08/2022 4:56 PM
And you tend to want enough subTokens floating around to "invest" in validators, payout rewards, hold for governance, float for grants to help build new things, etc. So there has to be an "economy" of sorts within the sub DAO. That is, because you want each subDAO to run on its own but be linked to the ultimate economic incentive model of HNT. The power of a programmatic treasury is that it gives you price determination rather than price discovery. Price discovery allows the market to decide the value of the subToken and to indicate to which the tokens should be invested. Price determination allows for a fixed incentive to hold, invest, etc without having to match a buyer with a seller every time. My argument against a zero slope in the programmatic treasury equation is that if zero then why bother with the added headache of the DNT. Just leave it in HNT. My other argument of a zero slope is that if you don't keep it in HNT then it is just a gimmick for unit bias. price = 1 * supply * whatever_ratio_you_decided_for_unit_bias
AndrewsMD 04/08/2022 5:08 PM
@tuschar, in your vote by token lock plan, will both the subDAO token and the corresponding conversion amount of HNT be locked for the duration of the lock period? And if HNT is not locked along with the locked subDAO token, is there any scenario where this corresponding HNT could be used elsewhere in the Helium ecosystem like â€œbank floatâ€ is today? (edited)
KeithR 04/08/2022 5:10 PM
Wouldn't only the DNT be locked? You can't also lock the corresponding HNT (unless the slope of the treasury equation is zero). Because the value in HNT would be determined by when you converted it back into HNT.
17:11
Now effectively the HNT can't be removed from the treasury because those DNT are locked, but the amount of HNT would correspond to when any other DNT was withdrawn or more HNT deposited.
17:12
Which then kind of forces the validators to reside within the subDAO.
KeithR
And you tend to want enough subTokens floating around to "invest" in validators, payout rewards, hold for governance, float for grants to help build new things, etc. So there has to be an "economy" of sorts within the sub DAO. That is, because you want each subDAO to run on its own but be linked to the ultimate economic incentive model of HNT. The power of a programmatic treasury is that it gives you price determination rather than price discovery. Price discovery allows the market to decide the value of the subToken and to indicate to which the tokens should be invested. Price determination allows for a fixed incentive to hold, invest, etc without having to match a buyer with a seller every time. My argument against a zero slope in the programmatic treasury equation is that if zero then why bother with the added headache of the DNT. Just leave it in HNT. My other argument of a zero slope is that if you don't keep it in HNT then it is just a gimmick for unit bias. price = 1 * supply * whatever_ratio_you_decided_for_unit_bias

KeithR 04/09/2022 3:19 PM
Speaking of the flywheel... A positive sloped treasury equation gives it a little extra thrust. It encourages HODL-ing the DNT. Which locks the HNT into the treasury. Which reduces the amount of HNT in circulating supply. It encourages investment in the subDAO of DC-consuming services. Which yields more DNT to the owner. Which increases DNT supply. Which increases the price in HNT, which increases HODL-ing. Validators at the L2 level specifically for the subDAO forces a large block of DNT to be locked as well.
15:22
. I am having troubles figuring out how you initialize validators in the subDAO (which presumably requires staking of DNT to exist) when the only way to accrue DNT is to earn DNT (which presumably requires validators to accomplish). (edited)
15:23
Also, we really really really really really need delegated staking!
15:24
Folks that stake in a validator pool should also be able to vote with those DNT in the governance of the subDAO.
KeithR
Speaking of the flywheel... A positive sloped treasury equation gives it a little extra thrust. It encourages HODL-ing the DNT. Which locks the HNT into the treasury. Which reduces the amount of HNT in circulating supply. It encourages investment in the subDAO of DC-consuming services. Which yields more DNT to the owner. Which increases DNT supply. Which increases the price in HNT, which increases HODL-ing. Validators at the L2 level specifically for the subDAO forces a large block of DNT to be locked as well.

Max - Just Max 05/23/2022 7:49 PM
The halvening schedule needs to be set at the Helium DAO level and all sub DAOs must follow IMO.
1
Max - Just Max 05/23/2022 10:09 PM
You canâ€™t have oracles pulling from a fixed percentage of the pot if that pot halves. You cut the amount of staked IOT in half every 2 years when itâ€™s based on a fixed percentage pot. No one is going to give up liquidity for such a low APR so the only option is to unstake. This will be magnified even more by the fact that you can just stake HNT for veHNT and join the delegation pot with the option to move to another sub-DAO and no cost to operate a validator. (edited)

iBRK4NULL 05/27/2022 5:24 PM
HIP-52: veIOT (1) Hotspot Self-Staking: Hotspots are able to delegate veIOT in their own name in order to increase the frequency of challenges to that hotspot. Are these bonus challenges? Otherwise, this would lead to a race contition where the poor HS have to constantly stake all their rewards, just to get challenged, and eventually the rich squeeze them out of all challenges. Poor HS owners would rely only on witness earnings. Whole clusters of poor HS owners could conceivably go silent.
Tushar 05/27/2022 5:32 PM
what do you mean by bonus challenges?
Tushar
what do you mean by bonus challenges?
iBRK4NULL 05/27/2022 6:48 PM
What do they mean by an"increase to the number of challenges to that hotspot"?
18:49
If they are taking away from those who can't afford to stake, it'll turn into a leveraging system that doesn't reward based on coverage.
Tushar 05/27/2022 6:50 PM
You donâ€™t have to only stake to yourself
18:50
If you stake you someone elseâ€™s hotspot you earn some of their incremental earnings
18:51
So those who canâ€™t afford to stake may still have stake delegated towards their hotspots if they have good locations
iBRK4NULL 05/27/2022 6:52 PM
Are they taking away, then?
Tushar 05/27/2022 6:52 PM
What do you mean?
iBRK4NULL 05/27/2022 7:03 PM
Changing the proportion of another hotspots rewards, unless they stake proportional to the average stake, which isn't going to be possible for everyone.
19:04
The rich get richer, and the poor get poorer. I just started, I can't compete with the whales that already have more than 10 HNT. (edited)

Tushar 05/28/2022 7:43 AM
yes there is a max. it is in the HIP
07:44
the intention of this design is to have staking help curate the blacklist and fight spoofers
07:45
and if a hotspot is proven to be spoofing, the tokens staked to that hotspot may be slashed (edited)
07:45
this makes the whole network more secure and helps honest hotspots earn more in aggregate because it fights spoofing

Max - Just Max 05/28/2022 4:31 PM
For the minimum amount of -10M, hotspots receive zero challenges. In either direction across zero from the y-axis, the challenge probability multiplier varies linearly with the veIOT staked.
16:31

16:32

16:33

16:34

Max - Just Max 05/30/2022 10:38 AM
In layman's terms (because I don't understand whats actually happening either) the 5G mappers will connect to every cell site within range and note the location, signal strength and possibly the connection speed on a predetermined interval. It will know which site goes to which carrier and then it will then compile data on those towers as a way of comparing.
hashc0de 05/30/2022 10:41 AM
Itâ€™ll scan rather than connect per se. It will attach to Helium cells that support the SIM, however and those attach events will generate mining rewards. All the data will back haul over lorawan

In layman's terms (because I don't understand whats actually happening either) the 5G mappers will connect to every cell site within range and note the location, signal strength and possibly the connection speed on a predetermined interval. It will know which site goes to which carrier and then it will then compile data on those towers as a way of comparing.

NL_Miniterror_NL 06/01/2022 9:00 AM
The hnt per epoch is calculated by the ammount of DC moved in the doa. If i understand correctly, if 5g does 60% and iot does the other 40 the hnt per epoch will be divided at the 60/40 ratio.. The ammount of iot per epoch is then calculated towards that 40%. Could be completly wrong but thats how i understand it. If the next epoch has a 70/30 ratio the exchange rate between iot/hnt will change accordingly

HeliumQuest 06/01/2022 10:55 AM

Max - Just Max 06/02/2022 12:17 PM
Couple more questions on the veIOT delegtation into hotspots part. Simply increasing the likelihood of being challenged does not create a linear increase in rewards (please refer to HIP-15). Generally speaking, the best hotspots are those that hear the most beacons (yes HIP-17 comes into play but lets remove transmit scale and the number of hotspots witnessing each beacon to simplify this). Simply beaconing more only increases your reward units for 1 factor - beaconing. A good example would be a hotspot with 10M IOT staked towards it that happens to not beacon in an epoch. This hotspot didn't earn any IOT as a result of the veIOT delegated to it. According to the example given in the HIP it is assumed that hotspot earned 10x what it should have earned as a result of the stake for so 90% of the earnings end up going to the guy who delegated for that hotspot even though it wasn't actually an incremental increase. I think a better mechanism to do this (if possible from a technical standpoint) would be A) to apply a multiplier to all reward units earned by that hotspot and have no increased challenge rate or B) only count reward units that are earned via beaconing as incremental increases in earnings or C) Add a multiplier to the "luck factor" of being chosen as a witness when the total number of witnesses exceeds the number of hotspots that can be rewarded for witnessing a challenge. I'd rather not tag Tushar but maybe @JMF can weigh in? (edited)
1
1
Max - Just Max 06/02/2022 12:37 PM
Some simple questions - is the voting minimum 100M IOT (ignoring the multiplier for the minimum but not for weighting) or 100M veIOT? There seems to be no advantage of delegating "against" a hotspot if no one is delegating "for" the hotspot. Is there also no downside to incorrectly delegating "against" a hotspot. There is also no minimum time to stake "against" or weighting for the amount of time so I should just watch the list of accused gamers on GitHub and stake against the hotspots in the time between they are accused and the time they are denied since there is no downside to being wrong and no upside to being first.
12:41
Will burned gamer veIOT correlate to a burning of HNT in the treasury (I'm assuming no so we can't have an HNT crank-ing as capcom described) What is to stop someone from delegating "for" gamer hotspots and pulling that delegation between the time they are identified and banned? It seems like there is considerable money to be made by delegating "for" Panther X hotspots for the first 13 days they are online then pulling the delegation on day 14. Finally, can I use delegated veIOT to vote? (edited)
AndrewsMD 06/02/2022 1:11 PM
Please forgive this question if previously asked and answered. Assume a wallet address operates a fleet of IoT devices, and the fleet shares rewards with hosts at a specific % (e.g. 20%). Can the owner of the fleet delegate specific hotspots with great set ups for staking with veIOT (equivalent of 100 HNT/hotspot) to maximize the frequency of challenges while leaving other hotspots alone? This enables the fleet operator to be selective and at the same time pay hosts with un-staked earnings. The host can then choose to do what they want with their earnings, while the fleet operator can stake their earnings as they deem appropriate.
AndrewsMD
Please forgive this question if previously asked and answered. Assume a wallet address operates a fleet of IoT devices, and the fleet shares rewards with hosts at a specific % (e.g. 20%). Can the owner of the fleet delegate specific hotspots with great set ups for staking with veIOT (equivalent of 100 HNT/hotspot) to maximize the frequency of challenges while leaving other hotspots alone? This enables the fleet operator to be selective and at the same time pay hosts with un-staked earnings. The host can then choose to do what they want with their earnings, while the fleet operator can stake their earnings as they deem appropriate.
Max - Just Max 06/02/2022 1:14 PM
Yes. You also don't have to delegate for your hotspots. You can delegate for any hotspot you want.
2
13:15
To delegate you have to first stake. You choose the amount you want to stake so you would pay your host then stake whatever you wanted.
Max - Just Max
To delegate you have to first stake. You choose the amount you want to stake so you would pay your host then stake whatever you wanted.

Max - Just Max 06/02/2022 1:24 PM
For example, consider the following closed system with Hotspot A, Hotspot B, User X, and User Y. X delegates 1M veIOT â€œforâ€ hotspot A and 4M veIOT â€œagainstâ€ hotspot B. Y delegates 5M veIOT â€œforâ€ hotspot A and 2M veIOT â€œforâ€ hotspot B. Tallying both scores, we have a net score of 6M veIOT â€œforâ€ hotspot A and -2M veIOT â€œagainstâ€ hotspot B.
13:24
Its net for and against not gross
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 06/02/2022 1:25 PM
Fair... maximum net staked
Max - Just Max
For example, consider the following closed system with Hotspot A, Hotspot B, User X, and User Y. X delegates 1M veIOT â€œforâ€ hotspot A and 4M veIOT â€œagainstâ€ hotspot B. Y delegates 5M veIOT â€œforâ€ hotspot A and 2M veIOT â€œforâ€ hotspot B. Tallying both scores, we have a net score of 6M veIOT â€œforâ€ hotspot A and -2M veIOT â€œagainstâ€ hotspot B.
AndrewsMD 06/02/2022 1:26 PM

100 HNT = 10 million veIOT correct?
Max - Just Max 06/02/2022 1:26 PM
incorrect. The exchange rate varies over time from IOT to HNT. veIOT is created by staking IOT for a minimum of 6 months and a maximum of 4 years. Every incremental increase in days is a linear multiple of the veIOT you get with a minimum multiple of 1x and a maximum of 100x
2
AndrewsMD
This section related to gamers. Correct?
Max - Just Max 06/02/2022 1:28 PM
Depends who you ask. That's how its written but I think its just a way to gamify subDAO tokens to stop people from selling

ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 06/02/2022 1:53 PM
