Users that delegate veIOT to hotspots receive 50% of any incremental earnings through increased challenge completion.

1
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 06/02/2022 1:58 PM
I stand corrected. Looks like they rebounded very nicely.
Max - Just Max
Couple more questions on the veIOT delegtation into hotspots part. Simply increasing the likelihood of being challenged does not create a linear increase in rewards (please refer to HIP-15). Generally speaking, the best hotspots are those that hear the most beacons (yes HIP-17 comes into play but lets remove transmit scale and the number of hotspots witnessing each beacon to simplify this). Simply beaconing more only increases your reward units for 1 factor - beaconing. A good example would be a hotspot with 10M IOT staked towards it that happens to not beacon in an epoch. This hotspot didn't earn any IOT as a result of the veIOT delegated to it. According to the example given in the HIP it is assumed that hotspot earned 10x what it should have earned as a result of the stake for so 90% of the earnings end up going to the guy who delegated for that hotspot even though it wasn't actually an incremental increase. I think a better mechanism to do this (if possible from a technical standpoint) would be A) to apply a multiplier to all reward units earned by that hotspot and have no increased challenge rate or B) only count reward units that are earned via beaconing as incremental increases in earnings or C) Add a multiplier to the "luck factor" of being chosen as a witness when the total number of witnesses exceeds the number of hotspots that can be rewarded for witnessing a challenge. I'd rather not tag Tushar but maybe @JMF can weigh in? (edited)
Tushar 06/02/2022 2:00 PM
i need to think more about this suggestion and have flagged it to the other authors of this HIP. fwiw HIP 52 is not up for a vote yet because we think there are still a few rough edges to iron out. i think you understand the intention of the mechanism, we need to think more about the edge cases in the implementation
2
Max - Just Max
Some simple questions - is the voting minimum 100M IOT (ignoring the multiplier for the minimum but not for weighting) or 100M veIOT? There seems to be no advantage of delegating "against" a hotspot if no one is delegating "for" the hotspot. Is there also no downside to incorrectly delegating "against" a hotspot. There is also no minimum time to stake "against" or weighting for the amount of time so I should just watch the list of accused gamers on GitHub and stake against the hotspots in the time between they are accused and the time they are denied since there is no downside to being wrong and no upside to being first.
Tushar 06/02/2022 2:00 PM
everything governance and staking related is in veIOT
Max - Just Max
Some simple questions - is the voting minimum 100M IOT (ignoring the multiplier for the minimum but not for weighting) or 100M veIOT? There seems to be no advantage of delegating "against" a hotspot if no one is delegating "for" the hotspot. Is there also no downside to incorrectly delegating "against" a hotspot. There is also no minimum time to stake "against" or weighting for the amount of time so I should just watch the list of accused gamers on GitHub and stake against the hotspots in the time between they are accused and the time they are denied since there is no downside to being wrong and no upside to being first.
Tushar 06/02/2022 2:01 PM
adding a minimum time to be staked for or against a hotspot is a good idea. thank you for the suggestion
Tushar
everything governance and staking related is in veIOT

I figured that was the case, not written that way in this version

Max - Just Max
Couple more questions on the veIOT delegtation into hotspots part. Simply increasing the likelihood of being challenged does not create a linear increase in rewards (please refer to HIP-15). Generally speaking, the best hotspots are those that hear the most beacons (yes HIP-17 comes into play but lets remove transmit scale and the number of hotspots witnessing each beacon to simplify this). Simply beaconing more only increases your reward units for 1 factor - beaconing. A good example would be a hotspot with 10M IOT staked towards it that happens to not beacon in an epoch. This hotspot didn't earn any IOT as a result of the veIOT delegated to it. According to the example given in the HIP it is assumed that hotspot earned 10x what it should have earned as a result of the stake for so 90% of the earnings end up going to the guy who delegated for that hotspot even though it wasn't actually an incremental increase. I think a better mechanism to do this (if possible from a technical standpoint) would be A) to apply a multiplier to all reward units earned by that hotspot and have no increased challenge rate or B) only count reward units that are earned via beaconing as incremental increases in earnings or C) Add a multiplier to the "luck factor" of being chosen as a witness when the total number of witnesses exceeds the number of hotspots that can be rewarded for witnessing a challenge. I'd rather not tag Tushar but maybe @JMF can weigh in? (edited)

AndrewsMD 06/03/2022 3:12 AM
Is there a less complicated way to directly reward community members who correctly identify gamers/bad actors without potentially harming legitimate set ups in any way? Most community members will do this for free on principle, but if they were given increased incentives, they may actively hunt them down with increased vigor. Give them 5 or 10% of the amount stolen/gamed or some other reasonable #? Perhaps the foundation considers to operate a separate reward bucket designed for this purpose? Just throwing an idea out for others to ponder. Could be applicable to HIPS 52, 53, & 64.
AndrewsMD
Is there a less complicated way to directly reward community members who correctly identify gamers/bad actors without potentially harming legitimate set ups in any way? Most community members will do this for free on principle, but if they were given increased incentives, they may actively hunt them down with increased vigor. Give them 5 or 10% of the amount stolen/gamed or some other reasonable #? Perhaps the foundation considers to operate a separate reward bucket designed for this purpose? Just throwing an idea out for others to ponder. Could be applicable to HIPS 52, 53, & 64.
Angry Pickle Bear 06/03/2022 4:33 AM
Yes, we will putting out a document shortly identifying the best practices to get anti-cheating efforts funded through the grants program, though there is no plan currently to offer a percentage of the amount stolen/gamed. My opinion on that (which doesn't matter btw) is that I'm concerned that there would be a perverse incentive for anti-cheat actors to wait before reporting cheaters until the bounty is larger. If subDAOs want a separate reward bucket for this specifically, that's definitely possible and would be up to the HIP authors and subDAO votersâ€”this is exactly what the mapper bucket in the proposed 5G subDAO is.
04:38
Grants identifying bad actors / improving detection or prevention methods are a high priority. But proposals should have a focus on 1. the longevity/viability of the method (especially if implemented on a large scale, made public, or discovered), 2. scalability of the approach, 3. measurable performance metrics to evaluate success. Grant form here, anti-cheating grant guide for proposals to come soon. https://heliumfoundation.notion.site/The-Helium-Grant-Program-18a0484cf8a1494bae9eb3497b77a3cf (edited)
1
Angry Pickle Bear
Yes, we will putting out a document shortly identifying the best practices to get anti-cheating efforts funded through the grants program, though there is no plan currently to offer a percentage of the amount stolen/gamed. My opinion on that (which doesn't matter btw) is that I'm concerned that there would be a perverse incentive for anti-cheat actors to wait before reporting cheaters until the bounty is larger. If subDAOs want a separate reward bucket for this specifically, that's definitely possible and would be up to the HIP authors and subDAO votersâ€”this is exactly what the mapper bucket in the proposed 5G subDAO is.

KeithR 06/08/2022 7:50 AM
The floor price will not be 1:1 in any sense. It will be HNT in the treasury divided by the current supply of IOT. There will however be a market price that is expected to be higher than that; especially as more data gets transferred over the network.

KeithR 06/08/2022 8:28 AM
850,000 hotspots versus 50,000 hotspots also makes a difference. If everyone convinces their family & friends to add a sensor to their life...yippee! Also the distribution of HNT between the two subDAOs is surprisingly influenced by the veHNT staked between the two. Economics strongly suggests that the staking will be appropriately distributed, so therefore the number of hotspots will likely be the bigger influence. A tad confusing, but reasonably easily predicted.
08:33

That would make $IOT nicely valued; which in turns puts value into $HNT. It should not be too hard for us, Nova Labs, and all the sensor companies to add one sensor to every other household. Or cheat and lease 1000 sensors to one company. We all need to do our part for this.

KeithR 06/08/2022 9:09 AM
90% of the households in the US can afford a sensor. They already have cell phones and cable tv and buy coffee from starbucks. Sensors add to your situational awareness of your world. There is something about everyone's world that they can be more aware of and benefit from that increased awareness. Whether it is checking on something less often, knowing about something more often, or being more accurate about something; it can help them. Sensors are not very expensive and the data is now super cheap thanks to us. Sensors will get cheaper. Sensors will become more readily available. Sensors will measure more things as they become abundant. Get out there and sell them sensors everyone. (edited)

HeliumQuest 06/08/2022 6:02 PM
When was the last time you bought an IOT sensor? Now go out and start asking that question on the street. I've spent a lot of time looking at the sensors. Getting someone to buy something they've been living without for years/decades during a recession is going to be a tough sell. The one exception to this being businesses that can't hire someone to save their lives (many) that can partially replace personnel needs with sensor efficiencies. The math on profitability via DC usage is not pretty for the next few years--which is why they needed to incentivize PoC. We've been told a sensor can send data for $1 per year. Now imagine your hotspot moves 100 sensors worth of data at that rate. Not great ROI. Yes, eventually sensors will be everywhere, and get cheaper to make, but until then... (edited)

HeliumQuest 06/09/2022 6:45 AM
The problem I see with a lack of fixed conversion rates is that you have double the volatility...and with HNT in the treasury being a moving variable too, now it's triple. So folks that don't follow religiously (other primary jobs than Helium) now have an extra task, trying to monitor three variables. Also, the limited number of exchanges there are for converting HNT into cash is a problem. I've got three exchange accounts already, but none deal in HNT. Even Nik Hawks talked about the hassle of cashing out HNT in his recent episode about wrapped HNT.

05:03

jhbr821 06/10/2022 5:06 AM
All of the economics of the relationship between HNT and DNTs is in the HIP, I admit itâ€™s complicated stuff and may take multiple (many) reads but itâ€™s in there
05:07
One additional point, DNTs cannot be redeemed at secondary market value for HNT, they can only be redeemed based on the fixed relationship between how much HNT is in the treasury and how much DNT is outstanding
ubi 06/10/2022 5:09 AM
So that's where the price volatility of the new earning would be in comparison with the current one directly in hnt? (edited)
jhbr821 06/10/2022 5:10 AM
Yes any volatility would be above a floor redemption set by that DNT -> HNT redemption

Anthonyra 06/10/2022 5:53 AM
Let me know what you think! I wrote it for a couple reasons. I hate how crypto has become an early adopter gold rush and casino mixed together. I joined Helium in 2019 because I wanted a p2p wireless network that gave power to â€œthe peopleâ€. With 51-53 I have concerns; 1) Itâ€™s way to complex to achieve what they say these HIPs are suppose to do 2) To add a new sub-DAO you need to have it voted in (currently HNT and time locked weighted) but thereâ€™s no checks to prevent MOBILE from voting no on a competitor sub-DAO. 3) Thereâ€™s three knobs to determine a sub-DAOs rewards a) HNT locked as veHNT, b) # of devices which is defined by the sub-DAO, and c) the amount of DC the sub-DAO is using (only required to report this usage and no direct means for the Helium DAO to attest this data) all of these are driven by capital. HIP-63: 1) Tryâ€™s to simplify what the Helium DAO actually means and what it should be able to control. 2) My HIP wants to move to a yes or no based on a required stake (I call it a bond) like validators. This ensures existing sub-DAOs canâ€™t vote out competition. 3) The two knobs that influence rewards is age of the protocol and DC usage. The difference is that as protocol ages it gets less PoC and as DC usage exceeds the potential PoC reward it also reduces PoC. This seems counterproductive, and I suggest grabbing a coffee or preferred beverage. PoC is meant to bootstrap a network until DATA makes the network independent of PoC. So if the sub-DAO is pushing more data it shouldnâ€™t get a bigger chunk of the reward but instead less since itâ€™s indicates it doesnâ€™t need the bootstrap. 5G needs to be installed in places itâ€™s needed and not rewarded simply for owning the hardware. As an example, Iâ€™d say the same for LoRa. If 5G isnâ€™t moving any data then sure it should get PoC and vice versa (edited)

HIP-63: 1) Tryâ€™s to simplify what the Helium DAO actually means and what it should be able to control. 2) My HIP wants to move to a yes or no based on a required stake (I call it a bond) like validators. This ensures existing sub-DAOs canâ€™t vote out competition. 3) The two knobs that influence rewards is age of the protocol and DC usage. Ah. I was thinking the name changes depending on the function its currently performing. My head is as yet unwrapped around this.
15:47
IoT oracles confirm proof of coverage, data transfer, and add blocks to the IoT subnetwork. They serve state data around Proof-of-Coverage challenges and data transfer events to light and data only hotspots.
15:47

JMF 06/15/2022 10:57 AM
Sorry to go in a different direction here, but Iâ€™ve been floating the idea of having a minimum up front device fee for Lora sensors that is then available to the nodes via DCs? For example, $5 to add a sensor/node and the account gets $5 or DC (effectively unlimited data for most use cases). Imo it only increases the cost to setup marginally (say a sensor costs $20) but it could make Lora economics far more likely to be sustainable. There are a lot of complications to how that works technically, but I wanted to hear peoples opinion on the high level idea. Obviously, feeling out large sensor owners would be critical to any adjustment like this.
1
JMF
Sorry to go in a different direction here, but Iâ€™ve been floating the idea of having a minimum up front device fee for Lora sensors that is then available to the nodes via DCs? For example, $5 to add a sensor/node and the account gets $5 or DC (effectively unlimited data for most use cases). Imo it only increases the cost to setup marginally (say a sensor costs $20) but it could make Lora economics far more likely to be sustainable. There are a lot of complications to how that works technically, but I wanted to hear peoples opinion on the high level idea. Obviously, feeling out large sensor owners would be critical to any adjustment like this.
Max - Just Max 06/15/2022 11:02 AM
I would think as little friction as possible to add device would be better. What are the potential impacts both good and bad of â€œpre-burningâ€ HNT long before the DC is used?
JMF 06/15/2022 11:04 AM
Imo the friction is marginally different because you need to get DCs anyways and the cost of the sensors is significantly higher than the $5 for that.
11:05
It would mean paying $5 to activate and have unlimited data for most sensors.
groot 06/15/2022 11:07 AM
It would also mean that a big sensor user has tons of money locked up in unused DC that it might never need / could've used to deploy more sensors.
JMF 06/15/2022 11:08 AM
My concern is that thereâ€™s gotta be a way to actually drive some network revenue off the majority of nodes that use essentially $0.00 of data. Take this example, if there are 1 million crop sensors in the market that ping the network once per day and cost $20 each to buy. Right now that would be $20 M on hardware and $3,650 on data per year.
Max - Just Max 06/15/2022 11:09 AM
A 25% increase in price isnâ€™t nothing. If you are a large deployer you likely already have DC in your console
JMF 06/15/2022 11:09 AM
Vs $25 M all in and a much higher chance of having a sustainable network
11:09
Agreed itâ€™s not nothing but you still need a sustainable network underlying those nodes.
Max - Just Max 06/15/2022 11:10 AM
I think a lot of sensors will be primarily used on other networks then roam onto ours. It seems like a huge increase in price for those roaming partners.
groot 06/15/2022 11:11 AM
That's a lot of money you essentially have to lock up instead of the advertised pay as you go scheme. If that crop sensor user only has $20M to spend there are going to be less crop sensors aka less use, not more.
JMF 06/15/2022 11:11 AM
There could be other systems like $0.25 per month of connection, but I think $5 one time is cleaner
Max - Just Max 06/15/2022 11:11 AM
Especially if that DC is locked to that device. Whereas someone like senet can buy DC and use it on the devices that do roam on and not care if some of the devices never do
groot
That's a lot of money you essentially have to lock up instead of the advertised pay as you go scheme. If that crop sensor user only has $20M to spend there are going to be less crop sensors aka less use, not more.
JMF 06/15/2022 11:12 AM
Maybe 25% less sensors, 1,500X increase in network spend
11:12
I donâ€™t think it needs to be locked to the device. Another way to look at it is $5 for unlimited data (for most devices).
11:12
Just an activation fee that you get back in DCs
11:13
The big question for me is how does the network create enough revenue with the current model to be self sufficient when PoC is gone (long term)
groot 06/15/2022 11:13 AM
I think undermining the pay-as-you-go model and essentially pushing towards a traditional model is dangerous and might drive users into competing networks. Especially if they have competitive roaming in place that doesn't have this up front fee.

11:18

JMF
Sorry to go in a different direction here, but Iâ€™ve been floating the idea of having a minimum up front device fee for Lora sensors that is then available to the nodes via DCs? For example, $5 to add a sensor/node and the account gets $5 or DC (effectively unlimited data for most use cases). Imo it only increases the cost to setup marginally (say a sensor costs $20) but it could make Lora economics far more likely to be sustainable. There are a lot of complications to how that works technically, but I wanted to hear peoples opinion on the high level idea. Obviously, feeling out large sensor owners would be critical to any adjustment like this.
Fizzy 06/15/2022 11:47 AM
Questions, what happens to those whom are just testing devices as a developer, maybe they add a device just to test to see if their code works. Or testing for a client before adding it to a production console? Will these be attached to the keys? So deleting and re-adding will still have the same DC attached? In this cause, possible workaround is just use a single set of keys to for all your test devices, maybe? If not attached to keys, then the notion of removing any devices from console and essentially losing value is not a good look. High level, what will happen imo is you will have individuals or companies getting locked into a console services. Taking disk91s console as an example, where his DCs are at 5x the rate, could we expect him to charge $10-50 to onboard? Then if said customer is unhappy, or maybe disk91 closes it down, poof, they gotta pay all that over again with another console service. Something that was completely out of their control. While the above is extreme, and does have the same risk factors, the risk is scaled because you are talking about maybe 5$ you burned for DC for a whole console account for your 10 devices, vs 25$ (+whatever other upcharge) you burned for 10 devices. (edited)
Max - Just Max
So Nova, facilitates the burn of HNT to DC when the network has 1M devices but the actual DC is being used when there are 2M devices for example. You would assume that HNT that was pre-burned would have been worth more at the time it otherwise should have been burned since the network is bigger at the time of use compared to the time of burning.

lysanderG 06/16/2022 6:26 AM
If by "single use" you mean the sensor does one thing, then, yes, the vast majority of sensors (>95%?) will fall into that category. This is partly due to the complexity in the design to handle taking multiple measurements (and particularly power considerations) is difficult => expensive. (edited)
06:28
Also, bundling and unbundling multiple data points in a single payload given the data limitations with LoRa, further complicates things.
jhbr821 06/16/2022 7:42 AM

I think this depends on your State of residence. In Missouri, household batteries can go in the trash, but they recommend recycling--it's become harder to find places that recycle them, though.

KeithR 06/19/2022 12:46 AM
Your hotspot will only be rewarded with $IOT when the HIP is implemented. You can either withdraw the $IOT at the HNT 'floor price' via the treasury or you can sell on the secondary market (presuming there is one).

Delminium 06/19/2022 4:58 AM

Delminium
2,5m HNT / monthly how will this be distributed?
danggo 06/19/2022 7:16 AM
A subDAO's share of HNT Mint is based on its individual Utility Score compared to the sum of USc of all subDAOs. The better a Usc, the bigger the share of HNT Mint. (edited)

mcharliem 06/19/2022 12:44 PM
Long time follower here, first time posting. Iâ€™m excited for HIPs 51/52/53, but I have one main concern with how I understand them to work. This is an identical concern to what @KeithR had brought up a week or two ago, and I was curious if there had been a satisfactory explanation, because I hadnâ€™t seen one yet. The concern is with the idea that if IOTâ€™s share of distributed HNT is decreasing over time (as MOBILEâ€™s share is increasing) yet there is a constant amount of IOT being minted each period, then the ratio of HNT per IOT through redemption will also start to decrease over time. This will disincentivize anyone from ever holding IOT, and will encourage them to convert it immediately upon receipt. This seems like something weâ€™d want to avoid because people being encouraged to hold IOT is great for both IOT and HNT. It also seems like the solution to this problem would be: If there is a scenario where IOTâ€™s share of HNT is decreasing (because of MOBILEâ€™s comparative success) then there should be less IOT minted each period, instead of minting the same amount of IOT where each IOT is worth less and less. Does that make sense and is this still an open question? Or am I missing something? Like I said, Iâ€™m very excited for this next phase of the helium network but this one particular quirk has me concerned.
mcharliem
Long time follower here, first time posting. Iâ€™m excited for HIPs 51/52/53, but I have one main concern with how I understand them to work. This is an identical concern to what @KeithR had brought up a week or two ago, and I was curious if there had been a satisfactory explanation, because I hadnâ€™t seen one yet. The concern is with the idea that if IOTâ€™s share of distributed HNT is decreasing over time (as MOBILEâ€™s share is increasing) yet there is a constant amount of IOT being minted each period, then the ratio of HNT per IOT through redemption will also start to decrease over time. This will disincentivize anyone from ever holding IOT, and will encourage them to convert it immediately upon receipt. This seems like something weâ€™d want to avoid because people being encouraged to hold IOT is great for both IOT and HNT. It also seems like the solution to this problem would be: If there is a scenario where IOTâ€™s share of HNT is decreasing (because of MOBILEâ€™s comparative success) then there should be less IOT minted each period, instead of minting the same amount of IOT where each IOT is worth less and less. Does that make sense and is this still an open question? Or am I missing something? Like I said, Iâ€™m very excited for this next phase of the helium network but this one particular quirk has me concerned.
KeithR 06/19/2022 12:59 PM
I think it comes down to how we vote within the subDAO. "We" just need to vote in a responsible monetary policy. Hopefully that is not easier said than done. In my opinion, this means a simple rule needs to be followed; that is, HNT deposited into the treasury for that epoch must be part of the equation that determines how much DNT is minted. (edited)
mcharliem 06/19/2022 1:12 PM
So it sounds like itâ€™s still an open question. I agree the solution does seem rather straightforward, to have the amount of DNT minted linked to the amount of HNT deposited, but perhaps weâ€™re missing something. Iâ€™d be curious to hear from any of the HIP 52 authors on this specific question.
MyMomCallsMeJunior 06/19/2022 4:13 PM
I am having a hard time understanding the emissions distribution of IOT. rn, with HNT, up to 35% of rewards can go to hotspots for data transfer. If it ends up being less than 35%, the rest goes to PoC. With IOT, it says data transfer gets exactly 50% (not up to) and PoC also gets exactly 30%. does this mean that, no matter how much data is transferred in the network on a given epoch, 50% of that epoch's inflation always goes to data transferring?
AndrewsMD 06/19/2022 6:07 PM

mcharliem
So it sounds like itâ€™s still an open question. I agree the solution does seem rather straightforward, to have the amount of DNT minted linked to the amount of HNT deposited, but perhaps weâ€™re missing something. Iâ€™d be curious to hear from any of the HIP 52 authors on this specific question.
KeithR 06/20/2022 3:09 AM
As much as I hate the idea of uncorrelated minting of the subTokens, I have a suspicion that it is intended to allow each subDAO a greater sense of autonomy rather than dependence on performance. Why be a subToken when creating your own token is easy enough these days? What is Helium offering to a group trying to create a new network for some other protocol? I am assuming there are some that are thinking this is the only way to provide all the good of HNT and none of the baggage of being second class to the Helium project as a whole. While I understand that position, I am just too worried that it leads to poor monetary policy; and we have seen the last few weeks (and I suspect for the next few more) what happens to coins & tokens with bad monetary policies. (edited)
2
mcharliem 06/20/2022 3:39 AM
I think in theory, a subtoken should have leeway to mint and distribute their tokens how they choose, and thatâ€™s why this is fundamentally a HIP 52 question rather than HIP 51. But I also think itâ€™s clearly in the best interest of IOT holders for the subtokenâ€™s HNT exchange rate to not deteriorate over time, so thatâ€™s what we should strive for with HIP 52.
AlanIO 06/20/2022 4:30 AM
Hi Guys, I have a question about the initial price of IOT/HNT, because on the HIP it is written a fromula based on flowing HNT in the SubDAO treasury (Ht) / Outstanding supply of IOT (St), but at the end it is also written that only locked veIOT is considered in the outstanding supply. Can you please clarify ? St is the total supply in circulation (and therefore also the one mined by hotspots) or only locked supply for example of lorawan validators ?
AlanIO
Hi Guys, I have a question about the initial price of IOT/HNT, because on the HIP it is written a fromula based on flowing HNT in the SubDAO treasury (Ht) / Outstanding supply of IOT (St), but at the end it is also written that only locked veIOT is considered in the outstanding supply. Can you please clarify ? St is the total supply in circulation (and therefore also the one mined by hotspots) or only locked supply for example of lorawan validators ?
danggo 06/20/2022 8:41 AM
If you mean this: "The supply of IOT tokens for the purposes of calculating the IOT/HNT price includes all locked veIOT tokens." Most likely a typo. veDNT are not part of the programmatic treasury formula. It should rather say: "...includes all locked IOT in the veIOT voting contract." (edited)

But I also think itâ€™s clearly in the best interest of IOT holders for the subtokenâ€™s HNT exchange rate to not deteriorate over time, so thatâ€™s what we should strive for with HIP 52.
HeliumQuest 06/20/2022 2:13 PM
HIPs for each SubDao? I, for one, look forward to doing nothing but reading HIPs, MIPs, VIPs, and WIPs all day... (edited)
Rendezvous - wHNT 06/20/2022 6:47 PM

Sam217 06/21/2022 2:36 AM
What happens to the veIOT which are locked? As far as I understood, it's not possible to sell them and they are non transferable. So whenever I decide to unlock the veIOT, do I get my IOT back and are the staking rewards, I receive (which are also veIOT) exchangeable to IOT ?
KeithR
As much as I hate the idea of uncorrelated minting of the subTokens, I have a suspicion that it is intended to allow each subDAO a greater sense of autonomy rather than dependence on performance. Why be a subToken when creating your own token is easy enough these days? What is Helium offering to a group trying to create a new network for some other protocol? I am assuming there are some that are thinking this is the only way to provide all the good of HNT and none of the baggage of being second class to the Helium project as a whole. While I understand that position, I am just too worried that it leads to poor monetary policy; and we have seen the last few weeks (and I suspect for the next few more) what happens to coins & tokens with bad monetary policies. (edited)
AndrewsMD 06/22/2022 9:54 AM
I think we are on the same page here. I would argue that IoT tokens that are not minted according to a fixed ratio of IoT:HNT is a set up for inflationary pressures. The same holds true for all subDAOs. Each subDAO should determine their tokenomics with this in mind, and implement changes through governance as needed. Has this been discussed in an AMA that I missed?

JMF 07/06/2022 9:00 AM
That is generally accurate. In the beginning the algorithmic conversion protocol may be funky because it's starting from 0, but that will level out over time. It's also designed to be a backup to 3rd party exchanges, which obviously doesn't apply until there are 3rd party exchanges. That being said, I assume OTC options will arise almost immediately.

Max - Just Max 07/09/2022 6:48 PM
Well no, they could be different
Max - Just Max
Is removed from circulation different from burned?
danggo 07/10/2022 2:00 AM
A token being removed from circulation is sent to a burner address (receive-only wallet with no private key), which makes the removal permanent = burned. At least that's the common definition.
danggo
A token being removed from circulation is sent to a burner address (receive-only wallet with no private key), which makes the removal permanent = burned. At least that's the common definition.
Max - Just Max 07/10/2022 2:02 AM
Iâ€™m not asking a general crypto question. Iâ€™m asking if the plan is for every sub-DAO to burn their DNTs when they get redeemed or can they simply be placed in the treasury fund with the possibility of later being placed back in circulation.
02:07
subDAOs have full control over the prices at which the subDAO treasury provides quotes to holders of DNT who wish to redeem their holdings for underlying HNT. This can be a flat bid or a more complex curve. So in this case it is necessary to understand if they are being removed from circulation or burned because those are two very different things.
Max - Just Max
Iâ€™m not asking a general crypto question. Iâ€™m asking if the plan is for every sub-DAO to burn their DNTs when they get redeemed or can they simply be placed in the treasury fund with the possibility of later being placed back in circulation.
danggo 07/10/2022 2:10 AM
The HIP states that DNTs "sold" against the subDAO-Treasury are burned. So you are asking whether by using the phrase "burned" the authors follow the common definition or not. At least I've never heard of such a thing as a temporary removal from circulation. (edited)
danggo
The HIP states that DNTs "sold" against the subDAO-Treasury are burned. So you are asking whether by using the phrase "burned" the authors follow the common definition or not. At least I've never heard of such a thing as a temporary removal from circulation. (edited)
Max - Just Max 07/10/2022 2:20 AM
Where does it state that? I control Fâ€™d burn and the part you are referencing doesnâ€™t exist.
danggo 07/10/2022 2:22 AM
#hip-51-helium-dao under "End-to-End Process": "If a given address wishes to redeem their DNT, they can â€œsellâ€ against the subDAO treasuryâ€™s bid on the order book to receive the current rate of underlying HNT. The transaction involves selling the desired amount of DNT tokens on the order book, and receiving the determined amount of HNT tokens from the DEX. The subDAO automatically burns any DNT it purchases through this method."
danggo
#hip-51-helium-dao under "End-to-End Process": "If a given address wishes to redeem their DNT, they can â€œsellâ€ against the subDAO treasuryâ€™s bid on the order book to receive the current rate of underlying HNT. The transaction involves selling the desired amount of DNT tokens on the order book, and receiving the determined amount of HNT tokens from the DEX. The subDAO automatically burns any DNT it purchases through this method."
Max - Just Max 07/10/2022 2:30 AM

The only exception to this is the fixed cap of 6% DNT rewards going to veHNT stakers.â€ so itâ€™s a worthwhile question to ask since the response was weird

danggo 07/10/2022 3:07 AM
The subDAO DNT burn-mechanism is likely part of the basic subDAO-configuration that will be rolled out - and after that the basic config and its mechanisms will be open to changes via proposals on the DAO- or subDAO-level. veLRW is probably a(nother) typo, I hope. It used to say veIOT in that sentence. (edited)

Deleted User 07/12/2022 12:18 PM
We want to mine The IOT (edited)
MichaelBonesJones 07/13/2022 7:08 AM
Does anyone know if an IoT token will be worth the same as a HNT token? Will they be exchangeable 1 to 1, or will IoT have it's own separate value as a token? We don't want to go from mining HNT @ $10 to mining IoT @ $0.0001, unless we are mining 10,000 to 1, like a split. I can't find an answer to this anywhere, including today's blog post on HIP 51. If the value is different, how much different will it be, and will that be compensated for by more of it being available to mine?
MichaelBonesJones
Does anyone know if an IoT token will be worth the same as a HNT token? Will they be exchangeable 1 to 1, or will IoT have it's own separate value as a token? We don't want to go from mining HNT @ $10 to mining IoT @ $0.0001, unless we are mining 10,000 to 1, like a split. I can't find an answer to this anywhere, including today's blog post on HIP 51. If the value is different, how much different will it be, and will that be compensated for by more of it being available to mine?
jhbr821 07/13/2022 7:15 AM
There are 200 billion IOT which will be mined. They are emitted in a fixed amount each epoch, similarly to how a fixed amount of HNT is emitted each epoch. In addition, each epoch a certain amount of HNT will be deposited into the IOT subDAO treasury. The normally emitted HNT which is currently given to vals/hotspots will be split between the subDAOs (at this time MOBILE and IOT) based on the protocol score formula laid out in HIP 51. At any given time, IOT can be redeemed for HNT based on the formula: HNT in subDAO treasury/Circulating IOT. Thus the exact exchange rate is floating based on how much HNT has been deposited and how much IOT is outstanding. This exchange with HNT is meant to provide a floor price for IOT (buyer of last resort). IOT is expected to trade in secondary markets at some speculative multiplier. (edited)
3
MichaelBonesJones
Does anyone know if an IoT token will be worth the same as a HNT token? Will they be exchangeable 1 to 1, or will IoT have it's own separate value as a token? We don't want to go from mining HNT @ $10 to mining IoT @ $0.0001, unless we are mining 10,000 to 1, like a split. I can't find an answer to this anywhere, including today's blog post on HIP 51. If the value is different, how much different will it be, and will that be compensated for by more of it being available to mine?
jhbr821 07/13/2022 7:19 AM
To answer your specific questions: 1. IOT will trade separately as a token but will have a floor redemption value provided by HNT in the treasury, thus setting a floor for secondary trading due to arbitrage potential. 2. In theory there are about 100,000,000 HNT left to mine, some percentage of which will back 200B IOT, thus IOT is at a maximum worth 1/2000 HNT in terms of the floor redemption. (edited)
1

Does anyone know if an IoT token will be worth the same as a HNT token? Will they be exchangeable 1 to 1, or will IoT have it's own separate value as a token? We don't want to go from mining HNT @ $10 to mining IoT @ $0.0001, unless we are mining 10,000 to 1, like a split. I can't find an answer to this anywhere, including today's blog post on HIP 51. If the value is different, how much different will it be, and will that be compensated for by more of it being available to mine?

Another_AKA 07/19/2022 9:20 AM
Transactions initiated from both Apps and the Wallet CLI is experiencing a long queue (up to 6000 pending) before clearing. At this time, you may see that any on-chain transaction will take much longer than usual. Transactions include: - payments (sending and receiving) - transferring Hotspots - add Hotspots, update location - burn transactions Funds are safe, Hotspot mining is unaffected, the chain is still moving. https://status.helium.com/incidents/2f215q5wy8kp
Transaction Submission Delayed against ETL

MiloDal 07/19/2022 10:28 AM

MiloDal

jhbr821 07/19/2022 10:28 AM
Well it definitely can't be a 1-to-1 conversion if there are 200 billion IOT and a maximum of 100 million HNT to back them. As HIP 51 laid out, there is a protocol score such that minted HNT are deposited in the subDAO treasury which back the minted IOT. The conversion rate is not fixed. It floats based on how much HNT is in the treasury and how much IOT has been issued
Ay0hCrypto(ALCRYMIST) 07/19/2022 10:28 AM
max supply is *223m hnt (edited)

Well it definitely can't be a 1-to-1 conversion if there are 200 billion IOT and a maximum of 100 million HNT to back them. As HIP 51 laid out, there is a protocol score such that minted HNT are deposited in the subDAO treasury which back the minted IOT. The conversion rate is not fixed. It floats based on how much HNT is in the treasury and how much IOT has been issued

Off Chain Proof-of-Coverage We want to move the entire Proof-of-Coverage system off the chain so that an unlimited number of receipts can be validated off chain without affecting block times or consensus groups. We will start this work in earnest next week and communicate â€œwenâ€ as soon as we know.

KeithR 07/19/2022 12:51 PM
Isn't that because the validators are needed in the beginning? PoC work still needs to be done for some time for them to write the code for the oracles; no? And did I just figure this out correctly? The tokens being airdropped to "the validators" mean me (through Helium Rising)? So if I have 1000 HNT at HR, HR gets airdropped so that they can continue providing the service. Thus HR would allocate my portion to my account at HR. When we migrate to a new L1, those $iot would be distributed back to me via HR closing my account. Where does my 1000 HNT go? I assume HR distributes back to me; but when? As soon as we go live with $iot? 250k block cool-down starts when we go live with $iot? Or do I have to wait until we migrate to the new L1 to get both? deasydoesit 07/19/2022 3:15 PM
As I stated previously, even though HIP 52 still describes oracles as being staked, on-chain entities that will perform PoC in the new network configuration, people who've been following along know that oracles will be moved off-chain. Now, people can say, "off-chain oracles will be in a new HIP and it might not pass," but that is exceedingly naive. To have oracles on-chain, you need consensus, and to have consensus, you need to run your own chain. However, if you've been paying attention, Nova has stated that it won't be running its own L1 and will be migrating to a new L1 which, by logical extension, means that on-chain oracles won't be happening. You can argue till the cows come home about this needing a "HIP" and "said HIP might not pass" but if you really think Nova is going to allow the future of the network architecture to be decided in earnest by the smooth brains in this community, you're sorely mistaken. If push comes to shove, I promise you they will vote and/or gather the necessary votes to ensure the arch HIP passes to their liking. Given the above, and that on-chain oracles aren't going to be carried over to the new network architecture, there is no technological need to airdrop IOT to existing Helium validators as there won't be any on-chain oracle staking. The HIP acknowledges this technological requirement by stating We also propose a veIOT airdrop to Helium Validators as of the date of launch. This airdrop is required to transition the current Helium Validators into IoT subDAO Oracles. Since there is no longer a technological need for the validator airdrop, I do not believe the validator airdrop will be happening and that a future HIP describing off-chain oracles will state as much. (edited)
1
deasydoesit
As I stated previously, even though HIP 52 still describes oracles as being staked, on-chain entities that will perform PoC in the new network configuration, people who've been following along know that oracles will be moved off-chain. However, if you've been paying attention, Nova has stated that it won't be running its own L1 and will be migrating to a new L1 which, by logical extension, means that on-chain oracles won't be happening. You can argue till the cows come home about this needing a "HIP" and "said HIP might not pass" but if you really think Nova is going to allow the future of the network architecture to be decided in earnest by the smooth brains in this community, you're sorely mistaken. Ay0hCrypto(ALCRYMIST) 07/19/2022 5:12 PM
A userâ€™s veIOT lockup power is determined by 1) the amount of IOT they lock up with, and 2) the amount of time they commit to locking up their IOT. The structure applies a linear multiplier of time to the amount of HNT locked up in the voting contract. For the maximum period of four years, users receive 100x the veIOT. For the minimum period of six months, users receive 1x the veIOT. In a proposed system where Validators don't exist in the near future and Validators and Hotspots receive 50/50 the Original IoT and Earn more IoT than any other rewrded faction, while Validators would have 0 incentive to lock up their tokens more than 6 months. Hotspot owners could lock their tokens for 8+ months and totally control the veIoT governance system. That's something I don't believe. As many people have pointed out no one wants to give their power up, and validators hold most of it for now, why would they vote to move from a system where they hold a majority of the vote power to a system where they hold the minority?
Ay0hCrypto(ALCRYMIST) 07/19/2022 5:24 PM
53 reads much more believably: We also propose that 50B MOBILE are pre-mined at the launch of the network, and distributed to the subDAO operations fund administered by the Helium Foundation. Some fraction of this allocation is distributed over the course of the genesis period to live Mobile Network hotspots

So having â€œoff chain PoCâ€ is also just a type of oracle, that can have staking, etc. v1 might be a single oracle without staking, but Iâ€™d love for v2+ to be that anyone can stake and run a PoC oracle. 07:21

deasydoesit 07/20/2022 8:05 AM
The issue I'm having is that I co-run a validator company. Our customers are asking us how the HIPs will impact them, so we're forced to stay abreast of the contents of the HIPs and these channels to help convey information. By staying informed with both the HIPs and the related channels, we start to see contradictions where large portions of the HIPs are ostensibly being invalidated by comments made by people on the team. These contradictions affect our business, and our customers, so we communicate what we're seeing to try to manage expectations. That causes consternation across the board with us, our customers, and y'all. You tell us "wait for the HIP and don't make assumptions," I tell you "we waited for the HIP but, by statements made, the HIP is already outdated". The solutions I have are (1) don't release HIPs until they fully and accurately reflect the trajectory of the network so there's no room confusion and (2) get you an "alt" discord handle where you can say stuff as a human being and not have your comments read as coming from the CEO, similar to how the president has official and non-official potus accounts.
capcom 07/20/2022 8:07 AM
totally get it. but you're not waiting for the HIP, you're guessing at how things might work based on things i say in discord off the cuff. for example i saw you asking/complaining about how the decision to move to Solana was made, when no such decision has been announced anywhere, and if there was a decision like that the explanation of how the decision got made would be in the HIP. i think im just asking you to be a little patient, read a little less in to things I say because they are genuinely often only my opinion/desire or the result of me multi-tasking 20 things at once, and trust that you (as a validator company) are in the same boat as many others and have to be treated fairly. none of the work we're talking about here is going to get implemented overnight, and everyone (certainly myself) is very very sensitive to the situation with validator businesses and the amount of HNT staked
deasydoesit 07/20/2022 8:38 AM
Cap, I outlined both my frustrations and proposed solutions above, and hope you can understand my frustrations and take into consideration my proposed solutions. I acknowledge I have a propensity to grow animated when I get frustrated, and for that I apologize and will try to be better about expressing my feelings in such a combative way. I will make that promise to you, and I will keep that promise.

ferebee 07/20/2022 10:37 AM
Iâ€™ve been trying to follow both the HIPs and the tea leaves. Itâ€™s been difficult to judge the relevance of the HIPs at times, such as HIP-51 when there were no updates at all in March and April and we were all trying to figure out how bonding curves work and what they are good for. It would be a big help when trying to follow the development of HIPs like this if there were a way to gauge how far along various parts of the draft are. For instance, in March: is the Programmatic Treasury Specification final, or just an initial proposal? The Motivation section is final, right? It would also be great if we could get some sort of frequently updated timeline for the various stages of implementation. Obviously nobody can promise delivery dates, but it would help a lot to see the order in which things need to happen, such as â€œon 1 Augustâ€ or â€œnot before Q4â€ or â€œafter the choice of L1 has been finalizedâ€. A flowchart, updated weeklyâ€¦ For instance, some people seem to think the programmatic treasury reserve redemption function wonâ€™t be operational on 1 August, meaning we earn IOT but canâ€™t actually immediately redeem it for HNT. OTOH a literal reading of HIP-51 says that will definitely happen, meaning it will be implemented in the existing validators? Of course, no matter what you do, weâ€™ll always be asking for more clarity. Kudos for what we have. (edited)

NL_Miniterror_NL 07/21/2022 1:00 AM
Have you even read the hip that allows to expend the network with subdao's?
01:02
Short summary, mobile and iot can be exchanged to HNT according to the HNT in the treasury. Each dao will gets its own treasury and they will be filled according to the data usage per dao. So if mobile does 60% (measuered in different size, mobile is in gb and iot in kb) of datausage that treasury will get 60% of the HNT.
1
01:03
But read the main hip for the framework that actually allows subdao's on the network

NL_Miniterror_NL
Short summary, mobile and iot can be exchanged to HNT according to the HNT in the treasury. Each dao will gets its own treasury and they will be filled according to the data usage per dao. So if mobile does 60% (measuered in different size, mobile is in gb and iot in kb) of datausage that treasury will get 60% of the HNT.
c_s_t 07/21/2022 4:32 AM
Where does the HNT in the treasury come from? Already existing HNT? Or does it reduce the remaining HNT?
c_s_t
Where does the HNT in the treasury come from? Already existing HNT? Or does it reduce the remaining HNT?
NL_Miniterror_NL 07/21/2022 4:34 AM
Same as where it comes from now, but then it will be divided into the treasuries instead of being paid directly into wallets from Hotspot owners. The dividing happens according to the calculations from the data aspect per subdao.
04:35
So if 5g goes flop we lora users have nothing to worry about how much HNT we can exchange our IOT too, if 5G goes booming as they expect we Lora users will get way less HNT
04:36
Side note, if 5G goes booming as they are expecting the price of HNT to rise significantly so even though LORA users will be able to get less HNT for the IOT exchange to HNT they dollar value you mine per day should stay the same, but thats all guessing as nobody can look into the future (edited)
1
NL_Miniterror_NL
Same as where it comes from now, but then it will be divided into the treasuries instead of being paid directly into wallets from Hotspot owners. The dividing happens according to the calculations from the data aspect per subdao.

Woody
don´t agree, cannot count/estimate out of this description the effect for me. And if this is not possible then it is not well described.
KeithR 07/21/2022 1:17 PM
You can't estimate it now because it is a floating value. You would have to guess the amount of data used by $iot and the amount of data used by $mobile and how much veHNT was invested in each subDAO. And then you would have to estimate how much HNT had been deposited so far and how much has been withdrawn. You have have to estimate the amount of $mobile burned. And then you can make such an estimate. All of the variables are clearly indicated. It is well defined. Your ability to guess all the variables is very difficult, but you can't see the equation isn't well defined. And of course, you would have to estimate the value of %mobile on the secondary market as well to determine the best strategy. My point is, they have clearly indicated all the values and the relationships between those variables. You can make all the guess and assumptions you want now.

HeliumQuest 07/21/2022 1:46 PM
While what you describe is possible, it's unlikely. The VALUE of the HNT in each SubDAO may grow (and the value of the HNT you can exchange your particular token for may grow), but every SubDAO that gets added pretty much guarantees fewer HNT in each Treasury, thus dilution of each particular token. The hope is HNT appreciation outpaces the dilution (and that is my hope too), but let's be real with ourselves, it is just hope, and as they say, hope is not an investment strategy. (edited)

jhbr821 07/21/2022 2:11 PM

14:11

HeliumQuest
While what you describe is possible, it's unlikely. The VALUE of the HNT in each SubDAO may grow (and the value of the HNT you can exchange your particular token for may grow), but every SubDAO that gets added pretty much guarantees fewer HNT in each Treasury, thus dilution of each particular token. The hope is HNT appreciation outpaces the dilution (and that is my hope too), but let's be real with ourselves, it is just hope, and as they say, hope is not an investment strategy. (edited)
KeithR 07/21/2022 2:19 PM
My hope is that we litigate among us a better emissions rate for the subDAO tokens that doesn't lead to runaway printing of subTokens. I have capitulated on having a fixed rate based on HNT earned. Just seems to me that there has to be triggers and brakes for restricting the issuance of new $iot if the protocol is doing poorly. Otherwise, every token held will be deflating. (edited)
KeithR

Just seems to me that there has to be triggers and brakes for restricting the issuance of new $iot if the protocol is doing poorly. Otherwise, every token held will be deflating. (edited)

WOoBoiðŸ€ðŸ€ 07/22/2022 6:33 AM
hey guys. I see we are earning IOT starting in augustâ€¦ all said and doneâ€¦ what does this REALLY mean for us? are we getting screwed here? I avg 0.25 helium/day on my miner, how will iot be comparable?
06:33
what are the tokenomics of iot?
WOoBoiðŸ€ðŸ€
hey guys. I see we are earning IOT starting in augustâ€¦ all said and doneâ€¦ what does this REALLY mean for us? are we getting screwed here? I avg 0.25 helium/day on my miner, how will iot be comparable?
Another_AKA 07/22/2022 9:34 AM
Its the start of my day, and it feels like a speculation day, so I will bite and give you the only answer that is honest...no one knows/it depends. Another network is being added that will be taking from the overall pie of the daily/monthly HNT distribution (that is a good thing IMO for HNT appreciation). Starting out, if you convert your mined IOT into HNT, it will probably be nearish to .25 that you are averaging now, but it will be slightly less because 5G/4G operators can also convert their Mobile into HNT. The same amount of HNT distributed each day/month now is put into a IOT treasury and a Mobile Treasury for redemptions for IOT->HNT and Mobile->HNT. Now if Mobile use takes off (lots of DC burn) more HNT will be put in the Mobile treasury and less HNT in the IOT treasury. That's where you are thinking "that sucks, less HNT in the IOT treasury. man they are screwing the people that built the network. sticking it to the peasants again". And that will be where you are mostly wrong, IMO. If that happens, the value of HNT is going to move dramatically...in a positive manner. Yes, you will be getting less HNT for your IOT, but that HNT will be worth far more. Lots of valid concerns have been raised by smart people fearing IOT getting a big shaft if Mobile takes off like a saturn 5, but we are all hoping for that. This is my 10,000 foot level explanation. And my last opinion, If you want the payoff for a successful network rollout with multiple participants quit selling your HNT for fast food and coffees. Hold those damn things and see this played out. (edited)
7
2
Another_AKA
Its the start of my day, and it feels like a speculation day, so I will bite and give you the only answer that is honest...no one knows/it depends. Another network is being added that will be taking from the overall pie of the daily/monthly HNT distribution (that is a good thing IMO for HNT appreciation). Starting out, if you convert your mined IOT into HNT, it will probably be nearish to .25 that you are averaging now, but it will be slightly less because 5G/4G operators can also convert their Mobile into HNT. The same amount of HNT distributed each day/month now is put into a IOT treasury and a Mobile Treasury for redemptions for IOT->HNT and Mobile->HNT. Now if Mobile use takes off (lots of DC burn) more HNT will be put in the Mobile treasury and less HNT in the IOT treasury. That's where you are thinking "that sucks, less HNT in the IOT treasury. man they are screwing the people that built the network. sticking it to the peasants again". And that will be where you are mostly wrong, IMO. If that happens, the value of HNT is going to move dramatically...in a positive manner. Siegfried 07/22/2022 2:34 PM
"it will be slightly less because 5G/4G operators can also convert their mobile into HNT". How would that affect IOT miners? I don't see how. Whether the HNT that is distributed to the mobile subdao is in the treasury of that subdao or in the 5g miners wallets, who redeemed mobile for HNT makes no difference imo. Do I miss something here?
Siegfried 07/22/2022 2:49 PM
For me the biggest unknown will be the dynamics and effects of veHNT stake against different subdaos. If we look at the formula for the DAO utility score and the three components... (edited)
Siegfried 07/22/2022 2:56 PM
we see that - V, the variable dependent on staking of veHNT against a specific subdao isn't discounted at all, - while value of data consumption is discounted by a square root, and (16x data consumption -> 4x score increase) - number of active devices in a subdao discounted by 4th root. (16x devices -> 2x score increase)
15:00
Keeping in mind that up until now, all HNT earned by miners has been earned by Lora miners, and depending on how much they held, if most of HNT is still in the hands of Lora miners, couldn't they just acquire lots of veHNT, stake it against the Lora subDao and significantly shift the distribution of HNT between subdaos towards the Lora subDAO?
15:03
Result of this line of thinking is of course strongly depending on how much of HNT is owned by miners vs. non-miners (edited)
Siegfried
"it will be slightly less because 5G/4G operators can also convert their mobile into HNT". How would that affect IOT miners? I don't see how. Whether the HNT that is distributed to the mobile subdao is in the treasury of that subdao or in the 5g miners wallets, who redeemed mobile for HNT makes no difference imo. Do I miss something here?
Another_AKA 07/22/2022 3:03 PM
Yes. The same # of HNT is being mined every month. Right now 100% is going to Lora. The minute we are out of genesis, 5G/4G will start getting a piece of the HNT treasury. Right now Lora gets 100% of the treasury. Soon, it won't be 100% of the treasury. 5G/4G will get a % of the treasury. WiFi will get a % of the treasury. Lora will get less, howbeit negligible at the start.
Another_AKA
Yes. The same # of HNT is being mined every month. Right now 100% is going to Lora. The minute we are out of genesis, 5G/4G will start getting a piece of the HNT treasury. Right now Lora gets 100% of the treasury. Soon, it won't be 100% of the treasury. 5G/4G will get a % of the treasury. WiFi will get a % of the treasury. Lora will get less, howbeit negligible at the start.

Ok, I'm stopping right here. Keeping this at a 10,000 foot level where most people can comprehend what is happening to their IOT earnings. Staking, for/against, utility scores, changes everything. And yes, you may stake your hotspot and keep your earnings higher, but I'm not going into any of that with all the new questions here. I don't have a good grasp on all of that either, and I've read the Hips. I see max coming in, he seems to. None of the people posting these new questions know anything about those complexities. All they have read is "I'm no longer earning HNT? Now I'm earning IOT?" (edited)

Siegfried 07/25/2022 5:40 AM
@Jamalisms There is a spreadsheet that gives you an answer - if you make an editable copy ("file => create duplice/copy", sry using it in German, dk the exact English wording) you can type in values for variables of the formula that @Another_AKA so beautifully screenshoted. https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1up7-jJt3eM5Fn9K0NTnDA50ZzIDqV-bznbnwej1y3R4/edit#gid=2099369137 Problem is: the values are (1.) changing and (2.) partly unknown at the moment (edited)
05:41
I'll make some guesses here. First guess: Factor "V": veHNT staking will not be possible at the beginning, it is some months in the future afaik. So at the beginning, V=1 for each DNP. (edited)
05:43
Second guess: I start out not making guesses about data transfer at the moment. So I'll set the values = 1 also. (edited)
05:44
So I enter values for devices: We have 900.000 hotspots on IoT DNP, I'll 1/3 has been offline for quite a while. I discount to 800.000
05:45
Explorer shows 1730 5G hotspots. I'll up to 2000.
05:48
So effectively based only on device counts, we have 80% to Lora, 20% to Mobile, WiFi is not active atm, so 0. (edited)
05:48
Siegfried 07/25/2022 6:00 AM

Siegfried 07/25/2022 12:48 PM
Far from being an expert on this. But: I found these two quotes in the "Implementation section" of HIP 51 (https://github.com/helium/HIP/blob/main/0051-helium-dao.md#implementation "): "Phase I (Q2 2022) : As per HIP 53: Helium Mobile subDAO, MOBILE token is issued on the existing Helium blockchain. " "Phase II (August 1, 2022) : On the third anniversary of the Helium Network, the IOT token is issued on the working Helium blockchain" Does that answer your question?
1
Deleted User 07/25/2022 12:58 PM
Thx
Siegfried 07/25/2022 1:08 PM
One more thing: If I understand HIP 52 correctly, there will be an Airdrop of IOT tokens to all hotspots and validators that have been rewarded during the last 30 days (I call them "active"): "At launch of the IoT subnetwork, 2.5% of the total supply of IOT tokens (5B tokens) are issued and airdropped to oracles and hotspots on the existing IoT network." (see HIP 52, section "Emissions Curve"): https://github.com/helium/HIP/blob/main/0052-iot-dao.md#emissions-curve I am sure that a lot of people aren't aware of that. I suggest that this should be aggressively communicated throughout the community, especially using channels that are most likely to reach people who are less actively following the community news. (Is the helium app / wallet app capable of doing push notifications, e.g.?) Reasoning: (1.) It might incentivize people who have offline hotspots to reactivate them before end of the month. (2.) It will be better for the mood in the community if as many people as possible who might have offline devices and are able to activate them, know about this. It could send the message: "We still care about you. You are still part of this community. Your help is appreciated and we want to you back." @Joey 0x00003C @gristleking @rawrmaan (edited)
13:14
Given that HIP 52 schedules 65B IOT tokens to be minted in year one, this 5bn IOT airdrop roughly equal 7% IOT tokens minted in year one (or 2.5% of total max supply). And as far as I understand it: all (active) hotspots are equal in this. So for hotspots that are doing below average, this should be even more attractive. Can someone competent in this matter confirm that this Airdrop will happen on August 1st, if HIP 52 is approved (which we know for sure in about 6hrs)? (edited)
13:19
Siegfried
Given that HIP 52 schedules 65B IOT tokens to be minted in year one, this 5bn IOT airdrop roughly equal 7% IOT tokens minted in year one (or 2.5% of total max supply). And as far as I understand it: all (active) hotspots are equal in this. So for hotspots that are doing below average, this should be even more attractive. Can someone competent in this matter confirm that this Airdrop will happen on August 1st, if HIP 52 is approved (which we know for sure in about 6hrs)? (edited)

" "Phase II (August 1, 2022) : On the third anniversary of the Helium Network, the IOT token is issued on the working Helium blockchain" Does that answer your question?

Deleted User 07/25/2022 3:04 PM
I know I'm vastly confused by all of this seems after hip39 vote helium went in 102 different directions all at once and had made it next to impossible to keep up with it all
Deleted User
I know I'm vastly confused by all of this seems after hip39 vote helium went in 102 different directions all at once and had made it next to impossible to keep up with it all
Siegfried 07/25/2022 3:12 PM
1. Having the impression to not being able to keep up is not unusal when an organization/group of people grows. 2. To keep cool, precise language helps. In my view, we are not talking about 102 directions, but only a few main things, I summarize them as two things: (a) Light hotspot move - that had been planned a long time ago, if I understand correctly. So it is actually not a new thing, but something many of us weren't (fully) aware of. (b) 5G has actually been initiated before Hip39 vote, the L1-L2 / HeliumDAO+SubDao structure mainly has been a reaction to that. Of course, the details take time to understand. In general, trying to keep up with everything is an almost surefire way to lose one's sanity (learned that the hard way many years ago), prioritizing a few things usually helps. (edited)

Siegfried 07/26/2022 12:10 AM
In cases in which there is danger that short term holders vote rules in place to extract value short term, but those rules being disadvantageous long-term, I find the argument understandable that actors who lock-up tokens long-term should get more voting power for locking up tokens. Not sure if this relevant to Helium, but I wouldn't dismiss it without getting deeper into it. (edited)
2
Anthonyra 07/26/2022 3:14 AM
Iâ€™ve always thought itâ€™d be cool if when you voted for something. You lock-up a certain amount of HNT as your vote. Now, it only counts as one vote still. A snapshot of wallets is taken at a random time before the vote. But when you reach the majority or super-majority of either yes or no does it pass. If it doesnâ€™t reach either one of those itâ€™s remains open. That HNT used for voting is now a crowdfunded source of HNT for the developer to make the code. The HNT funded can be reclaimed in 3 months (made up number) Example: 1) 90% vote yes, 200 HNT in fund. The vote passes and will be implemented who ever codes it will get 200 HNT 2) No super majority wins, 1000 HNT in fund. Vote doesnâ€™t automatically pass or fail but who ever codes it will receive 1000 HNT and then itâ€™s implemented. 3) 90% vote no. Even if code exists it wonâ€™t be implemented. (edited)
Max - Just Max
Thereâ€™s a max supply of 223M (though that number is closer to 218M because of slow block times pre halvening and chain halts) and 124M have already been emitted to LoRaWAN network participants. It already happened
HeliumQuest 07/26/2022 4:44 AM
But Max, it's mint AND burn. The HNT minted don't stay in existence forever, just as damaged dollars are retired and new ones printed. As DC is redeemed and used HNT is burned so new HNT can be created. So yes, while there is an upper limit, that by no means translates into "124 M HNT will stay in Lora hands forever". People sell em (used to vote with em) etc. they get used and are replaced. I'm still not seeing how you've arrived at the conclusion "50% of HNT from now until eternity" stays/will go to Lora. (edited)
Siegfried
In cases in which there is danger that short term holders vote rules in place to extract value short term, but those rules being disadvantageous long-term, I find the argument understandable that actors who lock-up tokens long-term should get more voting power for locking up tokens. Not sure if this relevant to Helium, but I wouldn't dismiss it without getting deeper into it. (edited)
HeliumQuest 07/26/2022 4:59 AM
I see Max's argument, and I see yours too. Locking tokens should provide some stability against the volatility crypto is known for. That's a good goal. As an observer of crypto, I personally generally wouldn't want to lock up tokens so I couldn't move with the market, especially after seeing exchanges destroy billions in staked tokens because they were greedy and overleveraged. Then again, the world is basically overleveraged on the dollar, and I fear we've all only just begun to pay that piper. I'm really hoping Helium is different. If it is, I could see locking tokens to earn interest while I waited for my HNT to hit my "sell" threshold. (edited)

I don't know, but my guess is: the date is not fixed, it is a rough estimate. HeliumQuest 09/07/2022 1:12 PM
I think his point is you get taxed once on the IOT, then again on the HNT. This year will be my first dealing with the tax implications of owning crypto, but my understanding is you're taxed on the value of the token the moment you get it. So in my mind the question is, if IOT ends up having a value in a secondary fashion, will they tax you on that value, then again on the HNT value when you convert? (edited)
2

waveform 09/07/2022 4:50 PM
Not sure on US laws but I think they are the same as UK. Income Tax on 5G or Mobile as you earn it Capital Gains tax as you convert it to HNT Capital Gains tax as you convert HNT to fiat (but only on the difference between DNT>HNT and HNT>FIAT
waveform
Not sure on US laws but I think they are the same as UK. Income Tax on 5G or Mobile as you earn it Capital Gains tax as you convert it to HNT Capital Gains tax as you convert HNT to fiat (but only on the difference between DNT>HNT and HNT>FIAT

Adogg 09/08/2022 1:50 AM
Emission schedule proposed is front loaded. It should be reversed to incentivize network growth
01:54
Imo itâ€™s the glaring lesson that could be learned from the helium blockchain rollout. In the beginning everyone is making a killing incentivized exponential growth essentially a bubble then it pops and growth stagnates. They talk about scaling in hip 70. We need incentive to scale on the Lora side at least. Incentive is all but nil right now.
Siegfried 09/08/2022 2:29 AM
@Adogg please do not post the same thing in more than one channel.
Adogg
Emission schedule proposed is front loaded. It should be reversed to incentivize network growth
gtelnet 09/08/2022 4:09 AM
I'm not a tokenonics expert, but that sounds pretty brilliant. Starting a project with smaller emissions and doubling every two years, instead of halvening, sounds like it would better spread out and protect the incentives by reducing the amount of tokens the gamers could steal while devs plug the gaming holes, and give all ethical participants something to look forward to. Seems that design would create a longer and more sustainable period of growth, since there's more to be earned over time, even as more participants join.
1
04:10
Next project!
Anthonyra 09/08/2022 4:13 AM
But my early adopter rewards
gtelnet 09/08/2022 4:26 AM
exactly! i think that's the paradigm shift needed for future projects and i'm sure most early adopters would have still gotten involved; thinking of it terms of a traditional business, imagine a new company raises 200M in capital, they pay their first 10 employees 20M each for the first year, then as each round of investment decreases, the new and existing employees keeping make less, to the point no one wants to work there, unless they sell the heck out of their services/products to raise money, but motivation decreases for them, as their salary does; that's 100% the opposite of how most successful entrepeneurs start their business, where they start with a tiny budget and get people to work for peanuts in the beginning, with the promise of high earnings/stock options that will become worth something down the road.
1
gtelnet
I'm not a tokenonics expert, but that sounds pretty brilliant. Starting a project with smaller emissions and doubling every two years, instead of halvening, sounds like it would better spread out and protect the incentives by reducing the amount of tokens the gamers could steal while devs plug the gaming holes, and give all ethical participants something to look forward to. Seems that design would create a longer and more sustainable period of growth, since there's more to be earned over time, even as more participants join.

gtelnet
I'm not a tokenonics expert, but that sounds pretty brilliant. Starting a project with smaller emissions and doubling every two years, instead of halvening, sounds like it would better spread out and protect the incentives by reducing the amount of tokens the gamers could steal while devs plug the gaming holes, and give all ethical participants something to look forward to. Seems that design would create a longer and more sustainable period of growth, since there's more to be earned over time, even as more participants join.
HeliumQuest 09/08/2022 5:42 AM
It's an interesting idea, but it also has the potential to be inflationary and devalue the token. Imagine a doubling just at the moment the entire stock market goes into recession. Would people really still get into Helium if HNT dropped by a third in due to doubling emissions? I have doubts. One of the big arguments for the halvenings (even from bitcoin days) is that it is deflationary in contrast to a fiat which constantly hemorrhages value. (edited)
1
gtelnet
I'm not a tokenonics expert, but that sounds pretty brilliant. Starting a project with smaller emissions and doubling every two years, instead of halvening, sounds like it would better spread out and protect the incentives by reducing the amount of tokens the gamers could steal while devs plug the gaming holes, and give all ethical participants something to look forward to. Seems that design would create a longer and more sustainable period of growth, since there's more to be earned over time, even as more participants join.
Adogg 09/08/2022 11:22 AM

1
HeliumQuest
It's an interesting idea, but it also has the potential to be inflationary and devalue the token. Imagine a doubling just at the moment the entire stock market goes into recession. Would people really still get into Helium if HNT dropped by a third in due to doubling emissions? I have doubts. One of the big arguments for the halvenings (even from bitcoin days) is that it is deflationary in contrast to a fiat which constantly hemorrhages value. (edited)
Adogg 09/08/2022 12:05 PM
The total minted will be the same so if that were to happen it would be temporary. Price is deflated now and poc earnings are getting less. Where is the incentive there? That happens in both instances. (edited)
Adogg
The total minted will be the same so if that were to happen it would be temporary. Price is deflated now and poc earnings are getting less. Where is the incentive there? That happens in both instances. (edited)
HeliumQuest 09/08/2022 12:22 PM
I'm speaking about inflation and deflation in macroeconomic terms. Deflation is when your/consumer purchasing power increases. When bitcoiners speak of the halvenings being deflationary what they're saying is the smaller emitted supply means those who want coins have to pay more for them, meaning (generally) the coin value increases. Strictly speaking, what's happened to HNT's value isn't macroeconomic deflation (though I get what you're saying about the value of the token being way down). Value is down because the fiat economic system is tanking all stocks/coins due to irresponsible (inflationary) monetary policy and demographic chickens coming home to roost (aging populations, too few babies for too many years). Don't get me wrong, what you're proposing might actually work under normal economic circumstances, but I don't know that anything works in every type of economic condition (and I suspect it won't work in Recession). (edited)
HeliumQuest
I'm speaking about inflation and deflation in macroeconomic terms. Deflation is when your/consumer purchasing power increases. When bitcoiners speak of the halvenings being deflationary what they're saying is the smaller emitted supply means those who want coins have to pay more for them, meaning (generally) the coin value increases. Strictly speaking, what's happened to HNT's value isn't macroeconomic deflation (though I get what you're saying about the value of the token being way down). Value is down because the fiat economic system is tanking all stocks/coins due to irresponsible (inflationary) monetary policy and demographic chickens coming home to roost (aging populations, too few babies for too many years). Don't get me wrong, what you're proposing might actually work under normal economic circumstances, but I don't know that anything works in every type of economic condition (and I suspect it won't work in Recession). (edited)
Adogg 09/10/2022 11:45 PM
Recession is temporary and virtually everything is affected by it. I get that but itâ€™s affected with either minting schedule. The way I propose will be balanced with growth of the network. The value of the token just doesnâ€™t depend on scarcity solely. If we believe data transfer will increase like everyone says it will, the value will come from utility then eventually scarcity. Meanwhile the value miners get back will stay steady. (edited)

KeithR 09/11/2022 11:55 PM
Why is it taxed as you redeem your $IOT for $HNT? The $IOT, at the floor price, is an IOU for $HNT; you never valued the $IOT in fiat value (it was denominated in HNT the whole time; even though that value was floating). So it would be akin to converting your quarters for $10 bills. So income tax on the value of the redemption amount if it were HNT at that moment; then capital gains when you sell the HNT for fiat. No?
Adogg
Emission schedule proposed is front loaded. It should be reversed to incentivize network growth
KeithR 09/12/2022 12:04 AM
Your strategy works best if long-term steady growth is needed. If the case of LoRaWAN, there was an enormous need for exponential growth so as to solve the chicken-or-egg problem. So front-loading was not only justified, it was down right required. For 5G, the problem needing solving is not chicken-or-egg but a requirement for extreme growth to be effectively useful quickly. We are of no use to any of the MNOs until we have coverage rate that is fast enough to imply an ability to become ubiquitous. So unfortunately, front-loading of the rewards structure is once again needed.
KeithR
Your strategy works best if long-term steady growth is needed. If the case of LoRaWAN, there was an enormous need for exponential growth so as to solve the chicken-or-egg problem. So front-loading was not only justified, it was down right required. For 5G, the problem needing solving is not chicken-or-egg but a requirement for extreme growth to be effectively useful quickly. We are of no use to any of the MNOs until we have coverage rate that is fast enough to imply an ability to become ubiquitous. So unfortunately, front-loading of the rewards structure is once again needed.

KeithR 09/12/2022 2:25 AM
Why would it be taxed anywhere? If you are converting coins to bills, nothing to tax. As long as you redeem the HNT through the treasury, then the $IOT was always denominated in HNT. The $IOT is a pro-rata share of the treasury. (edited)
KeithR
Why would it be taxed anywhere? If you are converting coins to bills, nothing to tax. As long as you redeem the HNT through the treasury, then the $IOT was always denominated in HNT. The $IOT is a pro-rata share of the treasury. (edited)

Ernnt 09/15/2022 1:35 PM
