Ernnt
When will this be implemented? Do hotspot owners earn IOT from now on instead of HNT? Do we get the same amount of IOT that we have of HNT? Where can I find the answers to these questions?
Siegfried 09/15/2022 1:36 PM
If I remember right: 1. once move to solana is implemented. 2. No, that starts then. 3. No, you get lots more IOT. 4. HIP 52. Hotspot owners will earn IOT then, which they can redeem for HNT that has been distributed to the subDAO.
1
Ernnt
So hotspot owners will still earn HNT?
Siegfried 09/15/2022 1:37 PM
After the subDAO has been fully implemented, not directly. They will earn IOT. HNT that used to go to hotspots goes to an on chain "bank account" of the subDAO. IOT can be redeemed for HNT. Exchange rate is (Amount of existing IOT : Amount of HNT in "bank account"). Others (oracles, veHNT stakers toward subDAO, operations fund) will earn IOT too, so hotspot owners will only have a partial claim to the HNT in the treasury ("bank account") (edited)
KeithR 09/15/2022 1:37 PM
Read the HIP...
Ernnt
When will this be implemented? Do hotspot owners earn IOT from now on instead of HNT? Do we get the same amount of IOT that we have of HNT? Where can I find the answers to these questions?

Adogg

jhbr821 09/15/2022 6:42 PM
While this is technically true, the IOT value capture will not change. Previously HNT was only IOT so HNT reflected IOT value capture. Now IOT is spun off so it captures IOT value (this has not changed) while HNT captures value from IOT, 5G, and any other subDAOs. This is beneficial for your existing HNT while in no way decreasing the future value capture of IOT.
3
jhbr821
While this is technically true, the IOT value capture will not change. Previously HNT was only IOT so HNT reflected IOT value capture. Now IOT is spun off so it captures IOT value (this has not changed) while HNT captures value from IOT, 5G, and any other subDAOs. This is beneficial for your existing HNT while in no way decreasing the future value capture of IOT.
Adogg 09/15/2022 7:09 PM

While your existing Hnt might benefit, the iot devalues until dc burn catches up of which the iot subdao is the farthest behind. What iot speculates at no one knows but I doubt it will speculate as high as Hnt did. Hnt blew up because of concept, that concept and their own L1 none of that will be relative. The only thing that will grow iot is dc burn or restructuring of incentive. (edited)
jhbr821

Now IOT is spun off so it captures IOT value (this has not changed) while HNT captures value from IOT, 5G, and any other subDAOs. This is beneficial for your existing HNT while in no way decreasing the future value capture of IOT.

Danimal 10/08/2022 5:33 PM

half the strength 10/08/2022 10:51 PM
2500 iot = ??? hnt
half the strength
2500 iot = ??? hnt
Siegfried 10/09/2022 1:07 AM
The exchange rate is variable, depending on - the number of existing IOT tokens ("existing" meaning "ever emitted minus ever redeemed") and - number of HNT in the treasury (="bank account for HNT") of the subDAO. The exchange rate at the a specific epoch is the ratio of these numbers, because at any time, the entirety of of existing IOT represents a claim to the entirety of HNT in the treasury.
half the strength 10/09/2022 8:16 PM
if you mine 1 hnt a day now how much iot will you mine?
Siegfried 10/09/2022 11:34 PM
Very rough estimate: - If we assume data transfer being negligible(!) atm: Atm, monthly emissions are 2.5 mln per month, 61.15% going to hotspots reward pool, that's 1.529 mln HNT monthly rewards shared by all active hotspots. - Monthly IOT emissions in year 1: 65bln/12 = 5.417 bln IOT. 80% going to hotspots reward pool, that's 4.333 bln IOT. - 4.333 bln IOT /1.529 mln HNT = 2834 IOT per HNT. Mind that this is an estimate of the ratio of hotspot reward pool emissions sizes - it is not an estimate of the treasury exchange rate of IOT/HNT when redeeming IOT for HNT. (edited)
Siegfried
Very rough estimate: - If we assume data transfer being negligible(!) atm: Atm, monthly emissions are 2.5 mln per month, 61.15% going to hotspots reward pool, that's 1.529 mln HNT monthly rewards shared by all active hotspots. - Monthly IOT emissions in year 1: 65bln/12 = 5.417 bln IOT. 80% going to hotspots reward pool, that's 4.333 bln IOT. - 4.333 bln IOT /1.529 mln HNT = 2834 IOT per HNT. Mind that this is an estimate of the ratio of hotspot reward pool emissions sizes - it is not an estimate of the treasury exchange rate of IOT/HNT when redeeming IOT for HNT. (edited)
waveform 10/10/2022 5:24 AM
Its not even a rough estimate, its an example calculation
waveform
Its not even a rough estimate, its an example calculation
Siegfried 10/10/2022 5:25 AM
Ha. As a non-native English speaker I love to learn the nuances. What in your view is the difference between an estimate and an example calculation?
05:27
Nvm. Google helps
Siegfried
Ha. As a non-native English speaker I love to learn the nuances. What in your view is the difference between an estimate and an example calculation?
waveform 10/10/2022 5:31 AM
An estimate to me is a calculation that has some validity with the result based on the input numbers being accurate but not exact. A sample calculation would be one that has input numbers that have no guarantee of being valid. Eg Estimate: If my calorie burn is 100 per hour then if i dont eat for 1 day then I loose 2400 calories Sample: If my calorie burn is 1000 per hour then if i dont eat for 6 hours then I loose 6000 calories (Its pretty impossible to burn 1000 per hour, so its an example of how the calculation works but not an estimate)
1
Siegfried 10/10/2022 5:35 AM
What word would you use if I wanted to avoid a decision between one or the other? (And after that: back on topic) (edited)
Siegfried
What word would you use if I wanted to avoid a decision between one or the other? (And after that: back on topic) (edited)
waveform 10/10/2022 5:36 AM
Calculation. An estimate is providing a result that someone may accept as an answer.

What is the data consumption of MOBILE Now we can estimate the consumption of Data for IOT from the ETL reports Biut without knowing 1-4 we cannot calculate the % of HNT to the MOBILE or IOT treasuries. dpg 10/11/2022 2:18 AM
Do you have a copy in a google sheet or shareable version? Very interested in this as well to understand what the IOT airdrop implications are for the validators, given I understand they are receiving 50% of the initial 5B IOT tokens that are unlocking ?
dpg
Do you have a copy in a google sheet or shareable version? Very interested in this as well to understand what the IOT airdrop implications are for the validators, given I understand they are receiving 50% of the initial 5B IOT tokens that are unlocking ?
Siegfried 10/11/2022 2:57 AM
We may need some clarification on the airdrop. In the HIP, it is sometimes phrased as 'to oracles' and sometimes as 'to oracles and validators'. Reason: the Hip was written at a time, when the assumption was, that the airdrop would happen before validators are discontinued bc of HIP 70. (The HIP reads as if the assumption was, that validators would transform to or start running subDAO oracles). Afai understand, now the intended timeline is: first (1.) the move to Solana will be implemented, which also means discontinuation of validators, then (2.) IOT subDAO will be fully implemented. There just won't be any validators any more at that time. Oracles will be run by - not sure, either Nova or Helium Foundation - so that's where the airdropped IOT would end up, I guess. In any case, I assume the implication for validators is: none. They won't get any IOT airdropped. (edited)
dpg
Do you have a copy in a google sheet or shareable version? Very interested in this as well to understand what the IOT airdrop implications are for the validators, given I understand they are receiving 50% of the initial 5B IOT tokens that are unlocking ?

We may need some clarification on the airdrop. In the HIP, it is sometimes phrased as 'to oracles' and sometimes as 'to oracles and validators'. Reason: the Hip was written at a time, when the assumption was, that the airdrop would happen before validators are discontinued bc of HIP 70. (The HIP reads as if the assumption was, that validators would transform to or start running subDAO oracles). Afai understand, now the intended timeline is: first (1.) the move to Solana will be implemented, which also means discontinuation of validators, then (2.) IOT subDAO will be fully implemented. dpg 10/11/2022 1:15 PM
The HIP seems quite specific that IOT will be airdropped to validators "We also propose a veIOT airdrop to Helium Validators as of the date of launch. This airdrop is required to transition the current Helium Validators into IoT subDAO Oracles." ... "and is distributed to oracles and validators in the following proportion: Oracles: 50% of 5B tokens, distributed in proportion to HNT staked at the snapshot"
13:17
has it been stated anywhere how much IOT an oracle will need to stake?
dpg
The HIP seems quite specific that IOT will be airdropped to validators "We also propose a veIOT airdrop to Helium Validators as of the date of launch. This airdrop is required to transition the current Helium Validators into IoT subDAO Oracles." ... "and is distributed to oracles and validators in the following proportion: Oracles: 50% of 5B tokens, distributed in proportion to HNT staked at the snapshot"
Siegfried 10/11/2022 1:37 PM
Yes, that's something that is written in HIP51, but imho it is outdated. There is no (immediate) transition of current Helium validators into IOT subDAO oracles. Quote HIP 70: "Initially, we propose that the aforementioned oracles be built and operated by the Nova Labs team on behalf of the Helium Foundation. We believe that this will help the Helium network scale in the short term and immediately address concerns with scaling Proof-of-Coverage and Data Delivery. This will be revised in the long term to enable multiple Oracle operators to participate in these activities and ensure decentralization." https://github.com/helium/HIP/blob/main/0070-scaling-helium.md#multiple-oracle-operators (edited)
13:41
@Keenan Any idea whom to ask to make a definitive statement regarding the oracle aspect of IOT airdrop? (see above)
13:45
@dpg Maybe ask your questions at the Solana transition AMA Wednesday 19th (see events section of this Discord) to get definitive info. I guess many more people would like to have more clarity on that. (edited)
Siegfried
Yes, that's something that is written in HIP51, but imho it is outdated. There is no (immediate) transition of current Helium validators into IOT subDAO oracles. Quote HIP 70: "Initially, we propose that the aforementioned oracles be built and operated by the Nova Labs team on behalf of the Helium Foundation. We believe that this will help the Helium network scale in the short term and immediately address concerns with scaling Proof-of-Coverage and Data Delivery. This will be revised in the long term to enable multiple Oracle operators to participate in these activities and ensure decentralization." https://github.com/helium/HIP/blob/main/0070-scaling-helium.md#multiple-oracle-operators (edited)
dpg 10/11/2022 1:55 PM
The HIP 70 statement does not seem to contradict what is in HIP 52 as far as I can tell. IOT is airdropped to existing validators so that at some undetermined point in future when community run oracles are possible they will need that IOT to stake and run them (edited)

dpg 10/14/2022 7:18 PM
"We propose that as this infrastructure is deployed, the core developers and community introduce new HIPs that enable subDAOs to have multiple oracles, the specific coordination rules (consensus, etc), and discuss the potential of incentivizing these actors. Today, HIP 52 and HIP 53 propose such oracle rewards but do not specify the responsibility of those oracles or how they come to agreement. We propose that until a time that multiple oracle providers are online, this reward is not issued to the single oracle, Nova Labs, or the Helium Foundation." I see no wording in that suggests the IOT airdrop as outlined in HIP52 wouldn't go ahead as it is written. If it was going to supersede elements of HIP52 then it should have been explicit about it for the avoidance of doubt

â“ˆâ’½â’¶â“‡â“€ 10/18/2022 8:26 AM
In fact, why is earning tokens for deploying and operating USEFUL sensors not a thing on Helium?! Earning IOT (or a token) for deploying useful sensors. It drives LoRa traffic and you earn by deploying sensors...this might further incentivize startups/companies from deploying interesting sensors if they (or their users) get rewarded for deploying. E.g. a pool monitoring sensor could be built by a startup (like Sutro or pHin which is gone) and then the operators/owners of those sensors earn IOT (or something else) for deploying those sensors and sharing the data from them. Pool maintenance companies could have fleets of them in customer's pools which helps the customer, and helps the pool maintenance company...and one of those two parties earns tokens.
08:26
I wish we had reserved IOT not for LORA, but for something that is actually IOT: the end devices. LONGFI should have been the token name for existing Helium mining IMO.
08:29
The realm of existing and future IoT devices cross many different wireless protocols (WiFi, LoRa, 4G/LTE/5G, Z-Wave, Zigbee, RF, etc)...we really should consider renaming the IOT token given that there is already a trademarked name for Helium LoRaWAN network: LongFi. IOT is too valuable of a currency name to uses just for LoRa. The long-term marketing value of an IOT token for future endeavors where it actually means something is important when the HIP52 token could be the LONGFI token. (edited)
â“ˆâ’½â’¶â“‡â“€
The realm of existing and future IoT devices cross many different wireless protocols (WiFi, LoRa, 4G/LTE/5G, Z-Wave, Zigbee, RF, etc)...we really should consider renaming the IOT token given that there is already a trademarked name for Helium LoRaWAN network: LongFi. IOT is too valuable of a currency name to uses just for LoRa. The long-term marketing value of an IOT token for future endeavors where it actually means something is important when the HIP52 token could be the LONGFI token. (edited)
BFGNeil - Trackpac.io 10/18/2022 9:16 AM
It's not longfi it's lorawan, and if you paid people a premium for using DC, watch the gamers onboard thousands of fake sensors to earn more
2
09:16
Remember $10k of DC in $20k of DC usage rewards out would not be good for the network
â“ˆâ’½â’¶â“‡â“€ 10/18/2022 10:19 AM
Yes, gaming is always an issue with any of these projects. If you leverage the new Matter standard for IoT devices and required devices to be verified through a chain of certificates back to the trusted manufacturers you can reduce gaming at least on one axis (e.g. you can't spin up a software sensor feeding in crap without having an actual cert from a trusted authority). The rewards could be miniscule for sensor data..the point is that it rewards deployment (and ideally consumption) of data from sensors.
10:19
My understanding is that LongFi is Helium's actual branding for LoRaWAN.
KeithR 10/18/2022 12:18 PM
Doesn't the pool company already benefit from deploying a fleet of sensors in their customers' pools? The business logic stands on its own; they save a truck roll to check on chemical levels. They have the ability to tailor the service to the customer's pool chemical profile. They can service more frequently if the sensor says the pool is dirty or less frequently if the chlorine is staying stable. So why do they need to be given an incentive for it? This is a great opportunity for a middleware service. Sell to the pool guy the sensors and the monitoring service. No need to provide an additional incentive, the business opportunity is worth a lot already.
1
â“ˆâ’½â’¶â“‡â“€
My understanding is that LongFi is Helium's actual branding for LoRaWAN.
BFGNeil - Trackpac.io 10/18/2022 1:35 PM
Longfi was a protocol they tried before settling on lorawan as it had more choices for sensor providers etc
â“ˆâ’½â’¶â“‡â“€
Yes, gaming is always an issue with any of these projects. If you leverage the new Matter standard for IoT devices and required devices to be verified through a chain of certificates back to the trusted manufacturers you can reduce gaming at least on one axis (e.g. you can't spin up a software sensor feeding in crap without having an actual cert from a trusted authority). The rewards could be miniscule for sensor data..the point is that it rewards deployment (and ideally consumption) of data from sensors.
BFGNeil - Trackpac.io 10/18/2022 1:36 PM
Doesn't matter if it's small, anything over 1:1 would cause people to game it like crazy for a return

Siegfried 01/17/2023 5:30 AM
A question regarding the implementation of the emissions schedule of the Lora subDAO: In HIP 52, the IOT emissions schedule initially was designed with halvings being in sync with halvings of the HNT emissions. The idea obviously was that the IOT subDAO will be online on August 1st, 2022, and the first halving would be exactly after 1 year (at the same date the next HNT emissions halving occurs). Now we all know, the IOT subDAO starts later. So I am wondering: 1. Will the IOT emissions schedule just run as laid out and the consequence being IOT and HNT halvings dates being out of sync? 2. Or will "year 1" just be shortened, so that the halving dates of the IOT emissions will still be in sync with HNT halving dates? I guess the latter (2). If so: How will the 65bln IOT that are scheduled for emission in year 1 be emitted? - Will they all be emitted, but just over a shorter time (meaning the remaining days until August 1st, 2023)? - Will less than 65bln IOT be emitted, with emissions per epoch being double the amount than it will be after the IOT emissions halving on August 1st, 2023? (Thus effectively decreasing IOT max supply) - Will a different option be chosen? (edited)

my expectation is that it won't be "soon" by any means. if we are going to do an actual design iteration on it, i'd suspect 9+ months before a few reasonable designs get to code (never mind having to decide which approach each subdao wants)
gtelnet 03/09/2023 4:18 PM

gtelnet 03/10/2023 2:47 PM
There is no "whole point" of any single sentence in a HIP. There were hundreds, if not thousands, of points made by community members during the draft discussion of all these HIPs, which lead to their final version. The text of a HIP will never capture all the points made during the discussion process and rather, just show the end result of the discussions. All these HIPs were written while we still needed validators for another 6+ months, so they were written to entice validators to keep their stake active, so that the network didn't shut down. Now that we're X days away from shutting down validators, it would go down in crypto rug pull history to create a HIP that says "let's vote to reverse the incentives from our previous votes and not give so and so the rewards we all previously voted on." What would be the point of that? Did the validator operators not do what was expected of them?
PaulM
Here's another thought, the pre-mine should only go to Active validators at the time of the migration. Around 1/4 of validators have been offline for months now...If the intent was to incentivize validators to keep operating, then it should go to the validators that kept operating. (edited)
gtelnet 03/10/2023 2:49 PM
That would have been an excellent point to bring up during the draft of the HIP! But at this point in the game, if the HIP didn't say they needed to be active, it would fall into the rug pull category to remove them from being eligible. Maybe they decommissioned them to save money, but left their stake active so that they could participate in the premine?
gtelnet

The text of a HIP will never capture all the points made during the discussion process and rather, just show the end result of the discussions. What would be the point of that? Did the validator operators not do what was expected of them?

gtelnet 03/10/2023 3:04 PM
At this point, the why is "because we voted on it". Hindsight will always be 20/20. And there be an even better idea three months from now. And nothing that we've voted on is going to cause irreparable harm. But telling someone you'll get X for doing Y, and then changing that a week before they finish doing Y, will never look good for any business.

02:44
Hopefully I've asked that the right way without breaking any rules
-r1ch
Can someone explain or point me in the right direction Regardless of which subdao token in Helium, as one mines a subdao and HNT is placed in the subdao treasury is there a mechanism that makes a difference whether one converts the subdao for HNT from the subdao treasury eg immediately vs yearly? Or is that conversion based on the market
waveform 04/01/2023 2:45 AM
Well the market is based on the HNT/IOT Floor price in the treasury. If there is 10K HNT in the IOT treasury and 10M IOT not outside the IOT treasury then the conversion is 1:1000. Not sure where immediately or yearly applies. But everything is live. (edited)

danggo 04/19/2023 10:52 AM
Your delegated veHNT amount against the total delgeated veHNT amount of all stakers in a subDAO determines your share of the 6%. (edited)
danggo
Your delegated veHNT amount against the total delgeated veHNT amount of all stakers in a subDAO determines your share of the 6%. (edited)

waveform 04/23/2023 3:15 AM
The blockchain now only knows about rewards as HIP-70 moved POC/DC transfer information to Oracles and the Oracles just tell the blockchain how much to pay you, not details of the work you did. And anyone can write a tool that looks at the oracles. Hotspotty and HeliumGeek are the two with most functionality at the moment

KeithR 04/25/2023 12:09 PM
The folks participating with me on trying to figure this out came to this from yesterday's data. We will be confirming our math again after tonight's close of the epoch. 0.03422661 $mobile per 1 veHNT 0.02576979 $iot per 1 veHNT Obviously, this is expected to change daily. Drastically during the 10-days land rush period as people figure that out. But I would think the change will be relatively small but consistent going forward; especially because of the ease of re-allocating your stake between the subDAOs.
